Damoiselle. By Richard Brome] London Printed by T. R. for Richard Marriot, and Thomas Dring [etc.]1653 [102] p. Preliminaries omitted The following plays have been taken from this source:
The Madd Couple well matcht City Witt Or, The VVoman wears the Breeches.
Play details
The city wit. Genre: Comedy. Date first published: 1653. Date first performed: 1630 ? THE CITY WIT, OR, The VVoman wears the BREECHES. A COMEDY.
Dramatis Personæ. Crasy, a young Citizen, falling into decay. Jeremy, his Apprentice. Sarpego, a Pedant. Sneakup, Crasyes Father in Law. Pyannet, Sneakup's Wife. Ticketa Courtier. Rufflita Courtier. LadyTicket. Josina, Crasyes Wife. Linsy-Wolsey, a thrifty Citizen. Toby, sonne to Sneakup. Bridget, Iosina's Maid. Crack, a Boy that sings. Isabella keeping Woman. Jonea keeping Woman.

editorialDecl.p:
The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Pyannet Bridget Carsy Sneakup Josina Linsey-Wolsey Crack Isabella Ticket Jeremy Jonea Lady Ticket Tryman Servant
Prologue/Epilogue Music Rufflita Sarpego Toby Combined speech

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

sp.p:
Quot quot adestis, salvete, salvetote
Gentlemen, You see I come unarmed among you, sine Virga aut Ferula, without Rod or Ferular, which are the Pedants weapons. Id est, that is to say, I come not hither to be an Instructor to any of you, that were Aquilam volare docere, aut Delphinum natare, to teach the Ape, well learned as myself. Nor came I to instruct the Comedians. That were for me to be Asinus inter simias, the fool of the Company: I dare not undertake them. I am no Pædagogus nor Hypodidascalus here. I approach not hither ad erudiendum, nec ad Corrigendum. Nay I have given my Scholars leave to play, to get a Vacuum for myself today, to Act a particle here in a Play; an Actor being wanting that could bear it with port and state enough. A Pedant is not easily imitated. Therefore in person, I for your delight have left my School to tread the Stage. Pray Jove the terror of my brow spoil not your mirth, for you cannot forget the fury of a Tutor, when you have lain under the blazing Comet of his wrath, with quæso Præceptor te precor da ---& amp;c. But, let fear pass, nothing but mirth is intended. But I had forgot myself, A Prologue should be in Rhyme, etcetera therefore I will begin again.
sp.l: Kind Gentlemen, and men of gentle kind,
There is in that a figure, as you will find,
Because we will take your ears as it were in Ropes,
I will nothing speak but figures, strains and tropes.
Quot quot adestis Salvete salvetote.
The Schoolmaster that never yet besought ye,
Is now become a suitor, that you will sit,
And exercise your Judgment with your wit,
On this our Comedy, which in bold Phrase,
The Author says has past with good applause
In former times. For it was written, when
It bore just Judgment, and the seal of Ben.
Some in this round may have both seen it, and heard,
Ere I, that bear its title, wore a Beard.
My suit is therefore that you will not look,
To find more in the Title than the Book.
My part the Pedant, though it seem a Column
Is but a Page, compared to the whole volume.
What bulk have I to bear a Scene to pass,
But by your favours multiplying Glass.
In nova fert Animus, then I will do my best
To gain your Plaudit among the rest.
So with the salutation I first brought ye,
Quot quot adestis, salvete salvetote.

div2.stage: Main text ACT. I. Scene I. A Dinner carryed over the Stage in covered Dishes. Exeunt. Enter Crasy, Jeremy. Set forth that Table Jer. A Table set forth with empty Mony-bags, Bills, Bonds, & Bookes of accompts, &c.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Will you not go in and dine, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: No: I am of other diet today.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: The whole company expects you.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: May they sit merry with their cheer, while I feed on this hard meat. And wait you within: I shall not change a trencher.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: Alas my good Master.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Here are the nests, but all the
sp.l: Birds are flown.
How easy a thing it is to be undone,
When credulous Man will trust his estate to others!
Am I drawn dry? Not so much as the Lees left?
Nothing but empty Cask? have I no refuge
To fly to now? Yes, here, about a groats worth
sp.stage: He takes up the bils & papers.
sp.l: Of paper it was once. Would I had now
Greensgroats-worth of wit for it. But it will serve
To light tobacco-pipes. Here (let me see)
Here is three hundred pound, two hundred here.
And here one hundred, and two hundred here;
Fifty; fifty; fifty; and one hundred here,
And here one hundred and fifty. Besides
A many parcels of small debts, which make
Two hundred more. I shall not live to tell it,
But put it up, and take it by the weight.
sp.stage: He puts the Bills & Bonds into a Bag.
sp.p: Oh me! how heavy it is! And, doubtless, so it would be At some man's heart. It troubles me a little.
Now what news?

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.l: My mistress, and your Mother Sir,
Entreats you to come to dinner.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: These they are; My debts,
That strike me through. This bag will never pay
Any of these.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Sir, shall I say you will come?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: How well it were, if any of my Creditors
Could once but dream that this were current money!

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: What shall I say?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Even what thou wilt, good Jeremy.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.l: Alas you know, this dinner was appointed
A friendly meeting for most of your Creditors,
And many of your Debtors.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: But I hope
Few of the last appear.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.l: None but some privileged Courtiers, that dare
Put in at all men's Tables. They are all set,
Your Creditors on one side, and your Debtors
On the other; and do only stay for you.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: To feed on; do they? Go. I will not come.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.l: I fear, Sir, you will overthrow the good
That was intended you. You know this meeting
Was for the Creditors to give longer day,
As they should find your Debtors to acknowledge
The sums they owe you. Sir I should be sorry
To see you sink, or forced to hide your head,
That looked as high, as any in the City.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Prithee go in. And if they seem to stay,
Pray them fall too; tell them I take this time
Only to order my Accompts, and that as soon
As they are full, and fit to talk, I will come:
Good Jeremie go.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: In troth I pity him---

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: A right good Boy thou art. I think on thee:
What must I do now? All I have is lost,
And what I have not, sought to be forced from me,
I must take nimble hold upon Occasion,
Or lie for ever in the Bankrupt ditch,
Where no man lends a hand to draw one out.
I will leap over it, or fall bravely in it,
Scorning the Bridge of Baseness, Composition,
Which doth infect a City like the Plague,
And teach men Knavery, that were never born to it:
Whereby the Rope-deserving Rascal gains
Purple and Furs, Trappings and golden Chains.
Base Composition, baser far than Want,
Than Beggary, Imprisonment, Slavery:
I scorn thee, though thou lovest a Trades-man dearly
And makest a Chandler Lord of thousands yearly.
I will have other aid. How now! Again?

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, you are undone.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Hast thou no news, Jeremie?

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Alas your Mother Sir---

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Why what of her?
Is there a Plate lost, or a Apostle-spoon
A China Dish broke, or an ancient Glass,
And stained with Wine her Damask tablecloth?
Or is the Salt fallen towards her? What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.l: Her mischievous tongue has over-thrown the good
Was meant to you.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: What Good, good Jeremie?

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.l: Your Creditors were on a resolution
To do you good, and madly she opposed it,
And with a vehement voice proclaims you a Beggar;
Says, you have undone her Daughter; that no good
Is fit to be done for you: And such a storm
Of wicked breath---

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: She is drunk; Is she not, Jeremie?

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.l: No Sir, it is nothing but her old disease,
The Tongue-ague, whose fit is now got up
To such a height, the Devil cannot lay it.
The learned School-master, Mr. Sarpego
Has conjured it by all his parts of speech,
His Tropes and Figures; and cannot be heard
In the furious Tempest. All your Creditors
Are gone in Rage; will take their course, they say.
Some of your Debtors stay, I think, to laugh at her.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Now deafness seize me. I disclaim my hearing. I defy my auditual part. I renounce mine ears. Mistress Pyannet, a desperate Palsey is on thy lips, and an everlasting Fever on thy Tongue?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: What raging Rout hath rent thy rest;
What Scold hath scutch'd thy sconce:

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: I will breath it to thy bolder breast, That asked me for the nonce. You understand or know, that here hath been a Feast made, to take up a ponderous difference between Master Sneakup your Father in Law, and yourself Mr. Crasy; and between most of your Creditors and Debtors. Food hath been eaten; Wine drunk; Talk past; Breath spent; Labour lost: For why? Mistress Pyannet your Mother in Law, Mr. Sneakups Wife (though she will be called by none but her own name) that woman of an eternal Tongue; that Creature of an everlasting noise; whose perpetual talk is able to deafen a Miller; whose discourse is more tedious than a Justices Charge; She, that will out-scold ten carted Bawds, even when she is sober; and out-chat fifteen Midwives, though fourteen of them be half drunk: this She-thing hath burst all. Demosthenes himself would give her over. Therefore hopeless Sarpego is silent.

div2.stage: Enter Pyannet, Sneakup, Sir Andrew Ticket, Rufflit, La. Ticket, Josina, Linsy-Wolsy.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p:
Oh, are you here Sir! You have spun a fair thread.
Here is much ado, and little help. We can make bolt nor shaft, find neither head nor foot in your business. My daughter and I may both curse the time, that ever we saw the eyes of thee.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Sir, you have the civil virtue of Patience in you. Dear Sir hear me.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: He says he hears thee, and is ashamed to see thee. Hast not undone our Daughter? spent her Portion; deceived our hopes; wasted thy fortunes; undone thy credit; proved Bankrupt?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: All was but my kind heart in trusting, in trusting, Father.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.p: Kind heart! What should Citizens do with kind hearts; or trusting in anything but God, and ready money?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: What would you, dear Father, that I should do now?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Marry depart in peace Sir. Vanish in silence Sir. I will take my Daughter home Sir. She shall not beg with you Sir. No marry shalt thou not; no, indeed Duck shalt thou not.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Be yet but pleased to answer me, good Sir. May not an honest man---

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p:
Honest man! Who the Devil wished thee to be an honest man? Here is my worshipful Husband, Mr. Sneakup, that from a Grazier is come to be a Justice of Peace: And, what, as an honest man? He grew to be able to give nine hundred pound with my daughter; and, what, by honesty? Mr. Sneakup and I are come up to live in the City, and here we have lain these three years; and what? for honesty? Honesty! What should the City do with honesty; when it is enough to undo a whole Corporation? Why are your Wares gummed; your Shops dark; your Prizes writ in strange Characters? what, for honesty? Honesty? why is hard wax
called Merchants wax; and is said seldom or never to be ripped off, but it plucks the skin of a Lordship with it? what! for honesty? Now (mortified my Concupiscence!) Dost thou think, that our Neighbour, Master Linsy-Wolsie here, from the son of a Tripe-wife, and a Rope-maker, could aspire to be an Alderman's Deputy; to be Worshipful Mr. Linsie-Wolsie; Venerable Mr. Linsie-wolsie; to wear Satin sleeves, and whip Beggars? And, what? By honesty? Have we bought an Office, here, for our towardly and gracious son and heir here, young Mr. Sneakup---

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Yes forsooth Mother.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: And made him a Courtier, in hope of his honesty? Nay, (once for all) Did we marry our Daughter, here, to thee; racked our Purses to pay Portion; left Country house-keeping to save charges, in hope either of thine, or her honesty? No, we looked, that thy Ware-house should have eaten up Castles, and that for thy narrow Walk in a Jewellers shop, a whole Country should not have sufficed thee.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: If my uncunning Disposition be my only vice, then Father---

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Nay, and thou hast been married three years to my Daughter, and hast not got her with Child yet! How dost answer that? For a woman to be married to a fruitful Fool, there is some bearing with him yet. (I know it by myself) but a dry barren Fool! How dost thou satisfy that?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: It may be defect in your Daughter, as probable as in me.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Oh impudent varlet! Defect in my Daughter? Oh horrible indignity! Defect in my Daughter? Nay, it is well known, before ever thou sawest her, there was no defect in my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
Well: If to be honest, be to be a fool, my utmost
Ambition is a Coxcomb. Sir, I crave your farewell.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Marry Sir, and have it with all his heart. My Husband is a man of few words, and hath committed his tongue to me: And I hope I shall use it to his Worship. Fare you well Sir.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Thanks for your cheer and full bounty of Entertainment, good Mr. Sneakup.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: He rather thanks you for your patience, and kind visitation, good Sir Andrew Ticket. Yes indeed forsooth does he.

sp.speaker: La. Tic.
sp.p: I take my leave Sir, too.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Good Madame---

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Uds so! there is a trick! you must talk, must you? And your Wife in presence, must you? As if I could not have said, good Madam. Good Madam! Do you see how it becomes you?

sp.speaker: La. Tic.
sp.p: Good Mistress Sneakup

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Good Madam, I beseech your Ladyship to excuse our deficiency of Entertainment. Though our power be not to our wish, yet we wish that our Power were to your Worth, which merits better service---

sp.speaker: La. Tic.
sp.p: Pardon me.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Than our rudenesse---

sp.speaker: La. Tic.
sp.p: You wrong yourself.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Can tender, or possibly express by---

sp.speaker: La. Tic.
sp.p: I beseech you forsooth---

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Our best labour, or utmost devoire. Yes I protest sweet Madam. I beseech you, as you pass by in Coach sometimes, vouchsafe to see me; and, if I come to Court, I will presume to visit your Ladyship, and your worthy Knight, Good Sir Andrew! And I pray you Madam, how does your Monkey, your Parrot, and Parraquitoes? I pray commend me to them, and to all your little ones. Fare you well, sweet Creature.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: We will leave you to take private farewell of, your Wife, Mr. Crasie.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: We will meet you at your Horse, brother.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: Loved, my dear heart, my sweetest, my very being, will you needs take your journey? I shall fall before your return into a Consumption. If you die but conceive what your departure will bring upon me, I know (my sweet) nay I do know---but go your ways; strike my finger into mine eye: It is not the first true tear a married woman has shed.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Why you hear the noise of that woman of Sound, your Mother. I must travel down, or not keep up. Yet ---

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: Nay, go I beseech you; you shall never say, I undid you. Go I pray: But never look to see me my own woman again. How long will you stay forth?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: A fortnight at the least; and a month at the most.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: Well, a fortnight at the least. Never woman took a more heavy departure. Kiss me. Farewell. Kiss me again. I pray does your Horse amble, or trot? Do not ride post as you come home, I pray. Kiss me once more. Farewell.
Hey ho! How I do gape.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: What is o'clock Bridget.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: Past three forsooth.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: It is past sleeping time then, Bridget.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Nothing is past to those, that have a mind and means.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: That is true and tried. Go lay my Pillow Bridget.
Lord, what a thing a woman is in her Husbands absence! Wast thou ever in love, Jeremy?

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Who I forsooth? Nor forsooth.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: Aye forsooth, and no forsooth? then I perceive you are forsooth. But I advise you to take head, how you level your Affection towards me: I am your Mistress; And I hope you never heard of any Apprentice was so bold with his Mistress.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: No indeed forsooth. I should be sorry there should be any such.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: Nay, be not sorry neither Jeremy. Is thy Master gone? Look. A pretty youth, this same Jeremy! And is come of a good Race. I have heard my Mother say, his Father was a Ferretter---

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: He is gone forsooth.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: Come hither Jeremy. Dost thou see this Handkerchief?

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Yes forsooth.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: I vowed this Handkerchief should never touch any bodies face, but such a one, as I would entreat to lie with me.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Indeed forsooth!

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: Come hither Jeremy. There is a spot on thy Cheek, let me wipe it off.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Oh Lord forsooth. I will go wash it.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: Heaven made this Boy of a very honest Appetite, sober Ignorance, and modest Understanding. My old Grandmothers Latin is verified upon him; Ars non habet Inimicum præter Ignorantem. Ignorance is woman's greatest Enemy. Who is within? Bridget.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Here forsooth.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: Go your ways to Mistress Parmisan, the Cheesemongers Wife in old Fishstreet, and commend me to her; and entreat her to pray Mistress Cauliflower the Herb-woman in the Old Change, that she will desire Mistress Piccadell in Bow-lane, in any hand to beseech the good old dry Nurse mother, Et cetera, she knows where, to provide me an honest, handsome, secret young man; that can write, and read written hand. Take your errand with you, that can write and read written hand.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: I warrant you forsooth.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: So, now will I meditate, take a nap, and dream out a few fancies.

div2.stage: Sene II. Enter Crasy, booted. Ticket, Rufflit, Tobias Sarpego, Linsy woolsy.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: We take our leaves Mr. Crasy, and wish good Journey to you.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Farewell good Mr. Crasy.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Adieu Brother.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Iterum iterumque vale.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Heartily Goodbye, good Mr. Crasy.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Nay but Gentlemen: A little of your patience you all know your own Debts, and my almost impudent necessities, satisfy me, that I may discharge others. Will you suffer me to sink under my Freeness? shall my goodness, and ready Piety undo me? Sir Andrew Ticket, you are a professed Courtier, and should have a tender sense of honour. This is your day of payment for two hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Blood of Bacchus, it is true, it is my day, what then? Dost take me for a Citizen, that thou thinkest I will keep my day? No, thou dost find that I am a Courtier, let my day keep me and it will. But dost hear? Come to the Court. I will not say what I will do for thee. But come to the Court. I owe the two hundred pounds: I will not deny it, if thou ask seven years hence for it, farewell. I say no more, but come to the Court, and see if I will know thee.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, now you are in favour, you will know nobody.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: True: it is just. Why should we, when we are in favour know anybody; when, if we be in disgrace, nobody will know us? Farewell honest Tradesman.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: That is Synonima for a fool. An ironical Epithet, upon my Facunditie.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Oh Master Sarpego! I know you will satisfy your own driblet of ten pound, I lent you out of my Purse.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Diogenes Laertiuson a certain time, demanding of Cornelius Tacitusan Areopagit of Syracusa; what was the most Commodious and expeditest method to kill the Itch, answered---

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Answer me my monies I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p:
Peremptorily, Careo Supinis; I want money. I confess, some driblets are in the Debit. But,
methinks, that you being a Man of Wit, Brain, Forecast and Forehead, should not be so easy, (I will not say foolish, for that were a figure) as to lend a Philosopher money, that cries, when he is naked, Omniamea mecum porto. Well Sir, I shall ever live to wish, that your own Lanthorne may be your direction; and that, where ever you travel, the cornucopia of Abundance may accompany you. Yes sure shall I. Vivevaleque.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Why look you Brother, It was thought, that I had a tender Pericranion; or, in direct Phrase, that I was an unthrifty fool. Seignior no: you shall now find, that I cannot only keep mine own, but other men's. It is rightly said, He that is poor in Appetite, may quickly be rich in Purse. Desire little; cover little; no not your own: And you shall have enough.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Enough?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Yes Brother, little enough. I confess I am your Debtor for the loan of some hundred Marks. Now you have need: who has not? you have need to have it. I have need to pay it. Here is need of all hands. But Brother, you shall be no looser by me. Purchase Wit; Get wit (look you) wit. And Brother, if you come to the Court, now my Mother and my Father have bought me an Office there, so you will bring my Sister with you, I will make the best show of you that I can. It may chance to set you up again, Brother; it is many an honest man's fortune, to rise by a good Wife. Farewell sweet Brother. Prithee grow rich again; and wear good Clothes, that we may keep our Acquaintance still. Farewell, dear Brother.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Mr. Rufflit---

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: What, does thy fist gape for money from me?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I hope it is not the fashion, for a Gallant of fashion, to break for so small a Portion as the sum of an hundred Angells.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: For a Gallant of fashion to break, for a Gallant of fashion? Dost thou know what a Gallant of fashion is? I will tell thee. It is a thing that but once in three Months has money in his Purse; A creature made up of Promise and Protestation: A thing that fouls other men's Napkins: towseth other Men's Sheets, flatters all he fears, contemns all he needs not, starves all that serve him, and undoes all that trust him. Dost ask me money, as I am a Gallant of fashion, I do thee Courtesy, I beat thee not.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I lent it you on your single word.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: It is pity but thou shouldst lose thy Freedom for it: you Tradesmen have a good Order in your City, Not to lend a Gentleman money without a Citizen bound with him: But you forsooth scorn Orders! By this light, it is pity thou loosest not thy Freedom for it. Well, when I am flush, thou shalt feel from me, Farewell. Prithee learn to have some wit. A handsome straight young fellow, grown into a pretty Bear, with a proper bodied Woman to his Wife, and cannot bear a Brain! Farewell. Dost hear? Be ruled by me, Get money, do, Get money and keep it; wouldst thrive? Be rather a knave than a Fool. How much dost say I owe thee?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Fifty pound.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Thou art in my Debt. I have given the Counsel worth threescore, Dog-cheap, well I will rent the odd money.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Strange mad fellows these same, Mr. Crasie, methinks to deal withal.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
You are right Mr. Linsie wolsie. I would my Genius had directed me, to deal always with such
honest neighbourly men as yourself. I hope you will not deny me a Courtesy.

sp.speaker: Lins.
sp.p: Not I, I protest, what is it?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: You took once a Jewel of me, which you sold for thirty pound, for which I have your Bond for sixty, at your day of marriage. If you will now, because I want present money, give me but twenty pound, I will acquit you.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: My good friend Mr. Crasie, I have no tricks and Jerks to come over you as the witty Gentleman had ere while: But I know a plain bargain is a plain bargain: and wit is never good till it be bought. If twenty pound will pleasure you, upon good security I will procure it you. A hundred if you please, do you mark Mr. Crasie? On good security. Otherwise you must pardon me, Mr. Crasie. I am a poor Tradesman Mr. Crasie, keep both a Linen and a Woollen Drapers shop, Mr. Crasie, according to my name, Mr. Crasie, and would be loath to lend my money, Mr. Crasie, to be laughed at among my Neighbours, Mr. Crasie, as you are Mr. Crasie. And so fare you well, Mr. Crasie.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Is this the end of unsuspicious Freeness?
Are open hands of Cheerful Piety,
A helpful bounty, and most easy Goodness,
Rewarded thus?
Is, to be honest, termed to be a fool?
Respect it Heaven. Bear up still merry heart.
Droop not: But scorn the worlds unjust despising.
Who through Goodness sinks, his fall is his Rising.

sp.p: Oh Master, Master, upon my knowledge, my Mistress is forced since your departure to be

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: What Jeremy?

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: Honest Sir. Get up your Debts as fast as you can abroad: For on my understanding (which great Iove knows is but little) she will take up more than your due at home easily.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Boy. Didst never observe at the Court gate, that the Lord was no sooner off from his Horse-back but the Lackey got up into the Saddle and rode home?

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Yes Sir, it is common.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I scorn not my Betters Fortune. And what is not my sin, shall never be my shame.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: In troth I was fain to make myself an Ass, or else I had been tempted to have been a knave.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Boy, thou art now my Prentice. From hence be free. Poverty shall serve itself. Yet do one thing for me.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: If it be in the power of my poor Sconce.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: If ever it be in thy possible ability, wrong all Men, use thy wit, to abuse all things, that have but sense of wrong: For without mercy, all men have injured thy mistrust-less Master, Milked my thoughts from my heart, and money from my Purse, and, last, laughed at my Credulity. Cheat, chosen, live by thy Wits: It is most manly, therefore most noble. Horses get their living by their Backs, Oxen by their necks, Swine and Women by their Flesh, Only man by his Brain. In brief be a knave and prosper: For honesty has beggared me.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: Farewell Master. And if I put tricks upon some of them, let the end of the Comedy demonstrate.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I am resolved I will revenge. I never provoked my brain yet. But now if I clap not fire in the tails of some of these Samsons Foxes---seems my defect of Fortune want of wit? No.
sp.l: The sense of our 'slight sports confessed shall have,
That any may be rich, will be a knave.

div2.stage: ACT. II. Scene I. Sarpego, Tobias. A Purse

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Egregious and most great of Expectation, my right dignified and truly Ciceronian Pupil, now that I have brought you into the Amoene fields with my ready thankfulness for the loan of this ten pound, I commit you to the grace of Court.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I shall expect that money shortly. Care to send it; For I purchased my place at a racked recompense.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Your Sarpego is no slippery Companion. You know I am to marry, and this money shall provide me Complements. Sis bonus o fælixque tuis. I pede fausto.

div2.stage: Exit Tob. Enter Crasy like a lame Souldier.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Beloved of Phoebus, Minion of the Muses, dear Water Bayley of Helicon, let it not be distasteful to thy Divine ears, to receive the humble Petition of a poor Creature, made miserable by the policy of Providence. That thy rare and absolute Munificence might supply what fortune had left defective: I kiss thy learned toes.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: I tell thee, by the Axioms of the Peripateticall Aristotle, thou art a Monster. My reward shall be therefore like thyself, monstrously lame. This is a figure in Elocution called Apoxegesis.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I am not fed with Figures Sir.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: You are an idle vagabond, and lie in wait for the blood of the learned. Labour, and live.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Right eloquent and well-phrased Sir, my education has been liberal. I sometimes fed my flock on horned Parnassus: But my wants forced me to my Sword.

div2.stage: He shews his blade halfe way.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: You did peradventure sip on the top of Science, Primoribus labijs, or so, but did not convert it in Succum& saguinem.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: That I may ever remain a true man. --- Extend.

The Sun, Moon and the seven Planets are my invoked witnesses, I should be grieved, that necessity should make me grow violent on so adored, adorned Grammatical Disciplinary ---Be gracious in Contribution ---Sir---

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: I will give thee an infinite treasure. Sis integervitæ, scelerisque purus. Vale poore Rogue.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Sir, this Sword can bite---But, I know you had rather give it freely out of your own Proclivity.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Yes I protest, as I am Erudite. Here dreadful Mavortian, the poor price of a Dinner.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: If I might in modesty importune the poor price of a Supper too.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: I do speak it in the Optative Mood, I do wish it lay in the model of my Fortune to give harbour to your shaken state, yet receive this with appeased clutch.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
If I might not seem audacious even to impudence, I poor Freshman in Literature, would implore
of your well-salted, and best seasoned virtue, some larger allowance to supply my defects of Raiment, Books, and other necessaries: which magnificence shall ever entitle you, my most bounteous Mecænas. Be induced to it Sir.

sp.speaker: Sar:
sp.p: Yes, yes, yes, that you may know how dear you are to me; Know this is more than usual largesse ---for non omnibus dormio---There is a Figure too.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Oh yes Sir, I understand this Figure too very well. Now dear Mecenas, let me implore a Purse to enclose these Monies in---Nay if you impart not with a cheerful forehead, Sir

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Væ misero mihi! sweet Purse adieu. Iterum iterumquevale.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: May you be importuned to do it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: You shall have it instantly. I will only deprome, or take out a little stuffing first.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: It is no matter. As it is, As it is, good Sir, as it is. I will accept it as it is. Most fragrant-phrased Master. suffer thyself to be entreated. Do---

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: You have most powerfully persuaded: Take it.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Most exorbitantly bounteous Mecenas, you have given me all this, have you not?

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Yes, yes, and you have taken all that, have you not?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Yes, yes, but as your gift. Iove bless thy brows, and make clear thy Physiognomy. Vale. Your learned Worship stinks.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Now Barbarism, Incongruity,

and false Orthography shame thee; The curse of Priscian take thee. All the parts of speech
defy thee. All the Interjections of sorrow, as Heu hei; of Shunning, as Apage; of Disdaining, as Hem vah; of Scorning, as Hui; of Exclaiming, as Proh Deum atque hominum fidem take thee. My dear Pupils lendings hast thou lewdly licked away: And sorrowful Sarpegois licked dry. There is a figure left yet! But Oh thou Castalion Traitor, Pick-purse of Parnassus, and Hang-man of Helicon: Dives thirst in thy Throat; Ixions wheel on thy back; Tantalus hunger in thy guts; and Sisyphus stone in thy Bladder.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Oh fearful curse! Well; I have given my first pinch, and a little scratched my Goat-bearded Grammarian, that Broke jests on my uncunning easiness. But he with the rest shall feel, that modest Simplicity is not always a defect of wit, but will. What my willing honesty hath seemed to lose, my affected deceits shall recover. I will rid them one after another, like Guts, till they shall stink worse than Jews. And they shall find with most ashamed eyes, The honest Breast lives only rich and wise.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: Bridget.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Here forsooth.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: Bridget, I say.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Here, Lady.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: That is comfortably spoken! Nay blush not: We women can never have too much given us. And Madam. Josina would sound well.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Yes indeed, Madam Josina Crasie.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: No; not Crasie; hang Crasie: Crasie is my Husbands name. I wonder why Women must be called by their Husbands names, I.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Oh, they must forsooth.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: And why not men by their Wives?

sp.speaker: Bri.
Ios.
sp.p: Is a married Man but half a Man? what is his other half then?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Truly, oftentimes, Beast. Which part the wife gives to boot, in exchange of her name.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: Hark, somebody knocks; go see. What should anybody knock at my Garden door for? I do not use to be visited in my Garden.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Yonder is a Gentleman craves admittance to converse with you.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: I will converse with no Gentleman. What have I to do with Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: A fair-spoken, comely, modest Gentleman he is.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: Is he so? I will speak with no modest Gentleman. You were best be his Bawd. But are you sure he is a true Gentleman? does he wear clean Linen, and lack Money?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Here he comes forsooth.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: He is very confident, and forward, methinks.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Exquisite; very Elixir of Beauty, vouchsafe to receive the tender of my Faith to you; which I protest is zealously devoted to your particular service.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: You may speak louder Sir: for I assure you, my Maid is very thick of hearing, and exceeding weak sighted.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Then, Lady, let it be spoken in bold phrase, I love you.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: I thank you Sir. How should I style you, pray?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
My name is Pulse-feel: A poor Doctor of Physic, that wears three-pile velvet in his Cap; has paid a quarters rent of his house afore-hand; and as meanly as he stands here, was made Doctor beyond the Seas. I vow (as I am right Worshipful) the taking of my Degree cost me twelve French crowns, and five and thirty pound of salt Butter in upper Germany. I can make your beauty, and preserve it; Rectify your Body, and maintain it; perfume your skin; tinct your hair; enliven your Eye; Heighten your Appetite. As for Gellies, Dentifrices, Diets, Mineral Fucusses, Pomatums, Fumes, Italian Masks to sleep in, either to moisten, or
dry the Superficies of your face; paugh, Gallen was a Goose, and Paracelsus a Patch to Doctor Pulse-feel. Make me then happy, dear sweeting, in your private favours: The which I vow with as much secrecy, constancy and Resolution, to preserve, as you, with Bounty, sweetness and Freeness shall impart.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: I protest you speak very far within me; I respect you most affectionately.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Then I will attend you at your Chamber: where the best pleasure, youth, Cupid can minister shall entertain you.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: Entertain me with pleasure? what pleasure I pray you?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Nothing but kiss you Lady, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: Well, for kissing and so forth, I care not; But look for no dishonesty at my hands, I charge you.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I will be provident.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: And honest, I beseech you: And secret, and resolute, I advise you.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: And very chaste I command you. But a kiss, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I understand you. This be my pledge of faith.

sp.speaker: Ios.
Cra.
sp.p:
Rely upon me. I can fit you rarely. I know a well qualified fellow, that danceth rarely, plays on divers
Instruments, and withal is close.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: Aye marry, Close! Pray let me have him. Kiss and adieu.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
I will maintain it. He only, that knows it, permits, and procures it, is truly a Cuckold. Some fellow would be divorced now. Crasie, speak; wilt be divorced? why, what if I were? why then thou art an Ass, Crasie. Why Sir? why Sir! why prithee tell me, what would thy Divorce hurt her? It would but give her more liberty. She should have bounteous Customers; Gallants, that would hoist her tires, bestow deep on her. And she should be paid for it. You speak somewhat to the matter Sir. Nay Crasie, believe it, though she be not a very modest woman for a Wife, thou mayst force her to be a reasonable private wench for a Whore. Say you so? By our lady, and I will take your Counsel. It is a pretty Drab. I know not where to compass such another? troth Sir, I will follow your advice.
And, if my hopes prove not extremely ill, I will keep her flesh chaste, though against her will.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.l: He took her by the middle so small
And laid her on the Plain:
And when he had his will on her,
He took her up again.
And what was she then the worse for wearing?
Can you tell Mr. Doctor?

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: What art thou?

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: One Sir (I dare tell you in private) that can conduct you to a more lovely Creature, than her you last courted.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: A young Pimp, a very sucking-pig Pimp! What an Age is this, when children play at such great game! So young, so forward!

sp.l: The young and the old mun to it, mun to it,
The young and the old mun to it;
The young ones will learn to do it, to do it,
And the Old forget not to do it.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: This Infant piece of Impudence amazes me. Prithee what art thou? or whom dost thou serve, or broke for.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: As delicate a piece of Woman-flesh as ever Mortal laid lip to. Oh she is all Venus! And, to come close to you, she wants a Physician. You are one I take it: I am a fool else.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: I am catched? This habit will betray me. What is she, I say.

sp.l: Oh she is, she is a matchless piece,
Though all the world may woo her;
Nor golden shower, nor golden fleece,
Is price enough to do her.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: For what wants she a Physician?

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p:
For what you please, when you come to her. Sir, upon my life, she is free from any Disease, but the Counterfeits. Will you know all Sir? she wants a wise man's counsel to assist her in getting a Husband. I take hold of you for that wise man, she relies upon my Election. Will you go Sir? It is in an exceeding civil
house; a precise one, indeed. Know you not Mr. Linsey Woolsey?

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Not at his house?

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Pardon me Sir. At his very house. All the wise wenches in the Town will thwack to such Sanctuaries, when the times are troublesome, and Troopers trace the streets in terror.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Prithee, what call'st thy Mistress?

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.l: Along along, where the Gallants throng
By twenties, away the Widow to carry:
But let them tarry: For she will carry
Twenty, before that one she will Marry.
Will you along Sir?

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.l: It is but a weak engagement: yet I will go;
Needless are fears, where Fortunes are so low.

div2.stage: Scene II. Enter Ticket and Rufflit.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: A widow! what is she? or of whence?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: A lusty young wench, they say: A Cornish Girl; able to wrestle down stronger Chines than any of ours.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: But how is she pursed, Jack? Is she strong that way?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Pretty well for a younger Brother; worth seven or eight thousand pound.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: How man!

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: You are a married man, and cannot Rival me; I would not else be so open to you.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: I swear I will help thee all I can. How didst find her out?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: I have intelligence, that never fails me, she came to town neither but very lately; and lodged at Mr. Wolseys.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Who, Linsy wolsie, the Hermaphroditical Draper! That is a precious Nott-headed Rascal. He will go near to aim at her himself.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Like enough. He may aim at her: But she will be hit by none but a Gentleman, that I hear too. Oh she has a fierce Ambition to a Ladyship, though her late Husband was a Tanner.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: A Tanner, well Jack, take heed how thou venturst on her to make her a Gentlewoman: She will kill thee at her Husbands occupation before thou wilt be able to make her Hide gentle. Thou wilt find a tough piece of Curriers work on her. Look who here is.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Truly Mr. Toby Sneakup, methinks I find an alteration in myself already.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Nay, I told you; would you but give your Mind to it, you would be a Gentleman quickly.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: How is this? let us stand aside a little.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Sure, he is about to turn himself into a Gentleman to win to the Widow!

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: And what a Tutor he has picked out to instruct him!

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Methinks I love the name of a Gentleman a great deal better than I did.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: But could you find in your heart to lend a Gentleman a score of Angells, Mr. Wolsey, on his word?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Uhm---It is not gone so far upon me yet.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Oh, but it most though, I know it. A Citizen can never be a Gentleman, till he has lent all, or almost all his money to Gentlemen. What a while it was ere the rich Joiners son was a Gentleman? when I myself was a Gentleman first, my money did so burn in my Pockets, that it cost me all that ever I had, or could borrow, or steal from my Mother.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: But Mr. Toby, a man may be a Country Gentleman, and keep his money, may he not?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: You see Sir, This Widow is removed from the Country into the City, to avoid the multiplicity of Country Gentlemen that were here suitors. Nay you must be a City Gallant; or a Courtier.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I see no Courtiers, but are more apt to borrow, than to lend.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Aye, those that were born, or bred Courtiers I grant you, But to come to it at your yeares---

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I can the sooner learn. Your Courtier Sir, I pray.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I will tell you in a brief character was taught me. Speak nothing that you mean, perform nothing that you promise, pay nothing that you owe, flatter all above you, scorn all beneath you, deprave all in private, praise all in public; keep no truth in your mouth, no faith in your heart; no health in your bones, no friendship in your mind, no modesty in your eyes, no Religion in your conscience; but especially, no Money in your Purse.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Oh that Article spoils all.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: If you do, take heed of spending it on anything but Panders, Punks, and Fiddlers; for that were most unfashionable.

sp.speaker: Lin.
Tob.
sp.p: Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Mr. Wolsie! Well met. How does your fair Guest at home, Mrs. Tryman?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: How should he come to the knowledge of her? Some of these Gallants will snatch her up, if I prevent not speedily.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Why speak you not Mr. Wolsie? How does the Widow?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Truly not well Sir. Whether it be weariness of her journey, change of air, or diet, or what I know not; something has distempered her.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Or Love, perhaps of you Mr. Wolsie.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Me? Alas, I look like no such Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: You may in a short time.
Hark hither Mr. Wolsie.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: We overheard you man: And I guest as much before.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: It is very true Sir, she is worth nine thousand pound: But marry she will not but a Gentleman: And I think I have beat him off on the condition. I have put him off of that scent for ever, with a false character, Heaven and the Court forgive me.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Thou hast In troth Boy: And on purpose to have her thyself, I perceive it.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: He does not. He is an Ass.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Well, if I were a Bachelor, I should envy thy wit, and thy fortune. Is she very handsome?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: So so: You shall see we will make a shift with her.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Mr. Wolsie, I would you had her with all my heart; you shall not want my good word and best wishes.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Do you speak this in earnest Sir, or as you are a Courtier.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: In earnest Aye, and as I am a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Then in earnest, and as I am an honest man, I do not believe you. Mr. Toby Sneakup has told me what Gentlemen and Courtiers are, too lately.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Mr. Sneakup, well met.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Good Mr. Rufflit.

sp.l: Now fair Maids lay down my Bed,
And draw the Curtains round:
Tell the World that I am dead,
And who hath given the wound,
Ah me poor Soul!
Alack for love I die,
Then to the Sexton hie,
And cause the Bell to toll.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Oh here he is! Mr. Wolsie, indeed my Master Wolsie, if ever you will see my Mistress your Sweetheart alive, you must go home presently.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: My Sweetheart!

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: I think she is; and that in death she will be so. I speak by what she says, and others think:

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: It is the Widows Boy,

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Is she sicker than she was.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Oh she is even speechless, and calls for you exceedingly. I fetched a Doctor to her, and he can do her no good. Master Sarpego has made her Will and all.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Has she given me anything?

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Quickly go and see Sir, you will come too late else, I am going to get the Bell to toll for her.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Fare ye well Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Tob., Tic., Ruff.
sp.p: Nay, we will along with you.

sp.l: Did never truer heart
Out of the World depart,
Or cause the Bell to toll.

div2.stage: ACT. III. Scene I. Enter in the Tryman, attended by Isabell, Jone, Crasy, with an Urinall.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Look up Mistress.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Take a good heart, the worst is past, fear not.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Ah, ah, ah.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Reach the Bottle again of Doctor Stephens water.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: No no, apply more warm clothes to her stomach, there the matter lies which sends this distemperature into her brain. Be of good cheer Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Is Mr Wolsie there?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Nothing but Mr. Wolsie ever in her mouth.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Pray Sir, how do you like her? I am much afraid of her.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Let me see, tonight it will be full Moon. And she scape the turning of the next Tide, I will give her a gentle Vomit in the morning, that shall ease her stomach of this conflux of venomous humours, and make her able to sit a hunting Nag within this seven-night.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: A rare man sure. And, I warrant, well seen in a Woman:

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Uh, uh, uh, uh.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Well said, spit out gently, strain not yourself too hard.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Agh---fagh.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: It is very well done. La you. Her colour begins to come. I will lay all my skill to a mess of Tewksbury Mustard, she sneezes thrice within these three houres---

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Good Sir want nothing, that your skill shall approve necessary in this time of need, Good Wives and kind Neighbours, I thank you for your cares.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Is Mr. Wolsie there?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: She does nothing but call for you Sir, pray speak to her.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Where is Mr. Wolsie.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Here Lady. How do you?

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Then I am even well methinks---agh---agh---

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: She is very far gone I fear, how do you find her disease Sir?

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p:
Dangerous enough Sir. For she is sicker in mind than in body. For I find most plainly the effects of a deep melancholy, fallen through her distemperature of passion upon her Liver; much disordering, and withal wasting the vitals, leaving scarce matter for Physic to work on. So that her mind receiving
the first hurt, must receive the first cure.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Agh agh ah---pagh fagh---

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: So so: Strain not yourself too hard. No hurt; so so. Here is melancholy and choler both in plenty.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: He speaks with great reason, mthinks, and to the purpose, I would I understood him.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Do you not know, Sir, any that has offended her by open injury, or unkindness?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Alas Sir, no such thing could happen since her coming hither.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Then, on my life, it is Love that afflicts her.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Oh Oh uh Oh---

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: I have touched her to the quick. I have found her disease, and that you may prove the abler Doctor in this extremity.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Who I? Alas I believe no such matter.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Mr. Wolsie, Mr. Wolsie.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Here he is Lady. Pray speak your mind to him. Must I pull you to her? Here he is. What do you say to him? Pray speak.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Oh no, no no no---

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: She hath something troubles her that concerns only you. Pray take her by the hand, do as I entreat you. Lady we will go, and leave you in private awhile, if you please.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Pray do. Oh but do not, pray do not.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Do you perceive nothing in this passion of hers? How does she feel your hand?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Oh, she does so quiddle it, shake it, and gripe it!

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: You are then the man Sir, the happy man. For she shall recover suddenly.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Who I? Alack a day.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: What will you have me die intestate. Is not my Will made, as I directed?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Where are you Mr. Sarpego, with the Will.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Ad manum. Sweet Buds of Generosity, forbear: you may Admirare, at the abundance here specified: But not find a Legacy bequeathed among you.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: We expect nothing.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: I only wish your health, Lady; and that it may, or might have been my happiness to sue to you for Love; as I do now to the highest power for Life.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Would I were married to her, as she is; and it were but for an hour, I cared not. Had my mother been but acquainted with her, before she fell sick, here had been a match!

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: O Dij immortales! A rich Widow shall have Suitors on her Death-bed.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Good Sir, It is too late to speak

of these things. I only crave and wish your prayers in your absence: This place can yield no pleasure to you I know. Mr. Wolsey, pray your hand again: I could be even content to live methinks, if I had but such a man as you to my Huh, uh, uh, uh.---

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: By your leave. Pray by your leave. Help Women. Bear up her Body a little. Bow it forwards. So, speak to her, Sir. Good Lady drink of this Cordial.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: How do you now forsooth?

sp.speaker: Cras.,
sp.p: What now she is drinking---Now speak Sir, you or no man must do her good.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: How do you forsooth?

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Well said Sir, speak cheerfully to her.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: How dee do? how dee do, Mistress Tryman How is it now, ha?

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Very comfortably spoken!

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Aye, was it not?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Alas she cannot speak. I will call my Neighbour Mistress Sneakup. If anybody can make her speak, it is she.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I will call my Mother for you. She will make her speak, if she have but a word left in her belly ---Masse here she comes.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: How comes it Mr. Wolsey, that you have a Gentlewoman sick in your house, and not send for me? Let me feel her hand. Alas she is shrewdly distempered. When had she a stool Sir, Prithee Daughter step home to my Closet, and bring the Viall of--- my own Water, which stands next to my blue Velvet Cabinet.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: That is my Doctor was with me today

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: She is a young Gentlewoman; may have many Children yet, let me note her eyes: I find nothing there. When did you see her water Mr. Doctor?

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: What Devil sent this fury among us?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: In troth I beshrew you, Mr. Wolsey, you sent not for me, but I hope I come not too late. Pluck up a Women's heart, you shall find a good Neighbour of me.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: I will thank you in my Will. I shall not live to thank you otherwise.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Alas talk not of your will. You shall have time enough to think of that many years hence.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: I tell her so, Lady, yet she calls for it still.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Pray let me see it, that I may sign it. Uh Uh---

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Lord how my Daughter stays. Good Sir Andrew Ticket! worthy Mr. Rufflit! My Son Tobias is highly honoured in your noble Acquaintance, and Courtly conversation.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: We rather hold ourselves dignified, in being his endeared Companions.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I assure you Mother, we are the three of the Court.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Oh welcome Daughter---I beseech you noble Sirs estrange not yourselves to us, your Servants.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Pox on your Complement.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Give me the Viall Daughter. Take up the Lady. Taste of this. It is a Composition of mine own distilling.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Uh, uh, uh, umh---

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Well done. Nay it will make you break wind, I tell you.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: By the service I owe you sweet Mistress, it is unfeigned. My Wife desires to see you.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
As I can best witness; And fears you enjoy not the liberty of a Woman, since your Husbands departure.
Your Brother having promised too, to conduct you to Court.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: It is confessed, and I will do it.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Where the best entertainment a poor Ladies chamber can afford, shall expect you.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: I shall embrace it.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Sfoot, it is time to part you---Mistres, I beseech your help, joined with your virtuous Mothers.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: You forget the young-man, that can Dance Write, and keep Counsel.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: I forget you not Lady. But I wish you to beware of these Courtiers, till I tell you what they are:

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: I will be hanged if this Doctor be not of her smock Counsel.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: How is it now, good heart?

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Much enlightened, I thank Heaven and you. Now, pray, read Sir my Will.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: In Dei nomine. Amen.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Oh let us hear the Will.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: I Iane Tryman of Knockers hole, in the County of Cornwall, Widow, Sick in Body, but whole in Mind, and of perfect memory, do make my last Will and Testament, in Manner and Form following.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: As for the Manner and Form it is no matter. To the Legacies, briefly.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Hum hum. Imprimis, A Dole of Bread to be given to the Poor of this Parish---five pound.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Stay. This I entreat of you Mr. Wolsey, that whether I live or die, this Dole may be given tomorrow. It was the Charge of my Mother to see it done; Saying, it was better to take the Prayers of the Poor with me, than leave them to be sent after.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: It shall be done: and you, I hope, shall see it.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p:
To Mr. Sarpego, the Writer hereof, A Mourning
Gown, and forty pound, to Preach at the Funeral.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: How! forty pound?

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Di boni! No. It is forty shillings. Item to my Nephew, Sir Marmaduke Trevaughan of Saint Minever, one thousand pound in Gold. Item to my Nephew Mr. Francis Trepton, one thousand pound in Gold. Item to my Kinsman, Sir Stephen Leggleden, I do forgive two thousand pound, for which his Lands are Mortgaged to me. Item to his Daughter, my God-daughter Iane Leggleden, five hundred pound in money; my best Bason and Ewer; two silver Flagon Pots, and three silver and gilt standing Cups. Item to the poor of the Parish of Knockers-hole, ten pound, and forty pound towards the reparation of their Church. Item to Mr. Linsey wolsey the Ring, which was my Wedding Ring, and fifty other Rings, with several stones in my Trunk, in his house, valued at two hundred and fifty pounds. Item to all his servants, and to the Women that attended me in my sickness, five pound a piece.

sp.speaker: Jone.
sp.p: Now the Lord receive her to his mercy.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: My Legacy will save her life; for never anybody died yet, that bequeathed me anything.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Item, to my Page Jeffery Crack forty pound. And all my other Servants ten pound a piece. Item to my Niece Barbara Tredrite five hundred pound; my second Bason and Ewer, a dozen of silver Dishes, and four dozen of silver Spoons. Lastly, all the rest of my Lands, Jewels, Plate, Money, Debts, Movables and Unmoveables, to my dear and loving Brother, Sir Gregory Flamsted, whom I make my full Executor. Incujus rei testimonium, &c. This is the brief of it.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p:
It is well. Only add to it---Uh---A Gold Chain also in my Trunk to this virtuous Gentlewoman.
And another Chain, that is there of Pearl, to her Daughter. To this learned Doctor twenty pound. And to the Gentlemen which have visited me, for them and their friends an hundred pound to be spent in a Banquet.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Hoc nihil refert. I must write all over again then.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Do so then. And make your forty shillings five pound.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Gratias vel ingentes ago. It shall be done---

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Now Mr. Wolsie, and your virtuous Neighbour here, I entreat, that when I have signed this Will, that you keep it till my Brother comes to Town. This Doctor shall direct you in all. And that he may be the better able so to do, I desire you all that I may a while be private with him.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: With all our hearts.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Are they all gone? Now Mr. Doctor, what think you of the sick Widow? Has she done her part hitherto?

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Beyond my expectation! Better than I for a Doctor.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: You are right. And I am even the same for a Widow as you for a Doctor. Do not I know you? Yes good Mr. Crasy. I dare trust you, because you must trust me. Therefore know, that I the rich Widow am no better, than a Lady that must live by what I bear about me. The vulgar translation you know, but let them speak their pleasure, I have no Lands, and since I am born, must be kept, I may make the best of my own, and if one member maintain the whole body, what is that to anyone?

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: I collected as much by your young Whiskin that brought me hither.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: It was by my direction that he did so. And, by my Instructions, he has had an Eye upon you in all your disguises ever since your pretended Journey out of Town. Nay startle not, nor muse at my acquaintance with you: I have had you in my Purlieus, before you were a Freeman: And will hereafter give you certain tokens of it. In the mean time, if you comply with me, you can be no loafer by it. I am grown weary of my old course; and would fain, by wiser, do myself good, before Age or Diseases make it too late.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I will work close and friendly with thee. Therefore say, this rich Coxcomb is thine own. Oh here comes your Pigg-wiggen.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: He is of Counsel, and one of us. He is indeed my Brother, and has been one of the true blue Boys of the Hospital; one of the sweet singers to the City Funerals with a two penny loaf under his arm.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Well: He never sung to the wheel in Saint Brides Nunnery yonder.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Nay Jeff, be not angry; thou hast sung to the Organs I know, till fearing their downfall, thou betookest thyself into my more certain service. All friends, good Jeff.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Yes, yes, we must all agree, and be linked in Covenant together.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: By Indenture Tripartite, if it please you, like Subtle, Doll, and Face.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Witty Jeff. I cannot see which can be spared from the rest, lest the whole trade break.

sp.l: Then let us be friends, and most friendly agree.
The Pimp and the Punk and the Doctor are three,
That cannot but thrive, when united they be.
The Pimp brings in custom, the Punk she gets treasure,
Of which the Physician is sure of his measure,
For work that she makes him in sale of her pleasure.
For which, when she fails by diseases or pain,
The Doctor new Vamps and upsets her again.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Thou art a brave Lad, and in the high way of preferment.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Not the high Holborne way, I hope Sir.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: And for you Damsel, as I said before, say to yourself, the Match is yours.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: I mean to say, and know it shortly. Some three days hence all may be completed. Now draw the Curtains; and follow your affairs, while I put on my sick Face again. Uh, uh, uh.

div2.stage: They put in the Bed, and withdraw all.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Now could I Accost that Catlinarian Traitor, that defeated me of my ten pound, I have a precogitated Oration should make him suspend himself. But Abiit, evasit, erupit. Or if the rich Widow would have died, there had been a supply. But she is nearer a Nuptial, than a Funeral: And hopeless Sarpego, that should wed, has not to furnish him to his intent, Væ mihi miseronec Aurum, nec Argent---tum! Here comes my Beatitude.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Oh, are you here Sir? I was to seek you. My old Mistress would speak with you instantly.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: My Legitimate Spouse, when is our day of conjunction?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Our day of conjunction? Marry faugh Goodman Fiste. Our day of conjunction?

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Did you not once vow you did love me?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Did not you once swear you had money?

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Hic jacet, I am now but a dead man.

div2.stage: Enter Pyannet, Sneakup, Crasie---like a Court-Messenger.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Oh where is Mr. Sarpego? Fortunate Mr. Sarpego? Venerable Mr. Sarpego? Oh Sir, you are made. Never think under right worshipful. Imagine nothing beneath Damask Gowns, Velvet Jackets, Satin Sleeves, Silk Nightcaps, two Pages and a Foot cloth.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: The Son of Phoebus rectify your Brain-pan.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Indeed, if it shall please your Worship, it is---

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: It is! What is it? You will be speaking, will you? And your Wife in presence, will you? you show our bringing up. Master Sarpego, bless the time that ever you knew the Progeny of the Sneakups: my worshipful Son and Heir apparent hath preferred you to be the young Prince his Tutor. Here is Mr. Holywater, a Gentleman; of place, a Courtier; of Office, is sent for you.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Right fortunately-learned Sir. So passionately doth his Grace approve the Language, Literature, and Behaviour of your sometimes Pupil, Master Tobias Sneakup.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Umh.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: That I was, with all expedition, commanded to entreat your instant Attendance.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Umh Umh---

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: It is even so Sir; You are like to possess a Princes ear; you may be in place, where you may scorn your foes; countenance your friends; cherish virtue, control vice, and despise fortune: Yes sure shall you Sir. And (which I had almost forgot) your old Pupil entreats you to send him by me the ten pound he lent you: An odd ten pound, that he may be furnished with the more seemly Complements to conduct you to his Grace.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Whist Mr. Sarpego. Let not your poverty be read in your face. Here is ten pieces. Bear it as your own payment: You talk of ten pound for my Son, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Oh, an odd driblet. Here, Friend, I use not to carry Silver: Convey it in Gold.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: I hope, dear Love, you will not forget your affection to me now.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Poor Maid, I will prefer thee to scratch my head; make my Bed; wash my Shirt, pick my toes, and evacuate my Chamber-pot. I will instantly procure me attire, fitting my fortune, and attend the Grace of Court---

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Now am I but a dead woman.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: I am much grieved for it. It was your sons much labouring, that Mr. Crasie was sent for, to sell his Grace some Jewels: But since his fortunes are so sunk that he hides his head, I can but lament his loss.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p:
Shall I tell you Sir, (pray you husband stand aside;) My Son-in-Law Crasie is not now worth ---his very wife. We hoped he would have proved a crafty Merchant, and he proved an honest man, a Beggar (if I chance to speak above your capacity, I pray tell me of
it) And as I said, when I perceived he began to melt, and that every stranger abused him; I, having some wit, fell too, and most cozened him myself. I looked for my daughters good: And so betwixt us, found the trick to get, or steal from him two Jewels of good deep value, being indeed the main of his rest of Fortune. Now Sir, I come to you.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Aye, now you come to the point.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Right Sir: For there is no woman, though she use never so many by-words, but yet in the end she will come to the point. Now Sir, I having these Jewels, will send them by my husband. A poor easy weak man, as you see; but very obedient in truth---

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: By your husband.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Yes, do you mark? By my husband. But now note my wit: His Grace knows not Crasie: My husband, habited like a Citizen, shall take the name of Crasie upon him; offer his Jewels to the Prince; you shall present them; praise them and raise them; His Grace pays; my husband returns; and we will share. Do you approve?

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Nay admire.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Away then. No Complement among

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Yes forsooth, I will carry them.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p:
La! you are so quick! I have charged you not to shoot your bolt, before you understand your mark. And you shall carry them like a Citizen; call yourself Crasie; sell them at my price; and now cast no further. You see the limits of your understanding. Now Sir, how will you bear yourself to his Grace?
How behave yourselfat Court?

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: I hope I am not too wise to learn.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Why, that was well spoken. Modest mistrust is the first step to knowledge. Remember that sentence. Now mark. I will instruct you: When you come at the Court gate, you may neither knock nor piss. Do you mark? You go through the Hall covered; through the great Chamber covered; through the Presence bare; through the Lobby covered; through the Privy Chamber bare; through the Privy Lobby covered; to the Prince bare.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: I will do it I warrant you. Let me see. At the Court gate neither knock nor make water. May not a man break wind?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Umh, yes: but (like the Exchequer payment) somewhat abated.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Through the great Chamber bare.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Covered.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Covered? Well: Through the Presence covered.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Bare.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Bare? I will put all down in my Table-book, and con it by the way.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Well thought on. Something he has in him like my husband! But now you come before the brow of Royalty. Now for your carriage there Sir: Suppose me the Prince. Come in, and present. Here sits the Prince. There enters the Jeweller. Make your honours. Let me see you do it handsomely.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Yes, now I come in; make my three legs--- And then---

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Kneel.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Yes; and say---

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Nay, that I know not.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: If it please your Grace, I have certain Jewels to present to your liking.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: If it please your Grace, I have certain Jewels to present to your liking.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Is this Crasie, that had wont to serve me with Jewels? It is that honest man, so please your Highness. That is for M. Holywater, the by-flatterer to speak. You are a Cuckoldly Knave, Sirrah, and have often abused me with false and deceitful stones.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: My stones are right, so please your Excellence.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Why that was well, Very well. I perceive there is a certain infection taken with lying with a woman that hath a good wit. I find it by my husband. Come, I will disguise you, and away to Court instantly.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Truly wife, I fear I shall be discovered among the Gallants presently.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: No, no. A fool is never discovered among madmen.

div2.stage: Scene III. Enter Tryman, Crasy. Crasy in his Court habit.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p:
Well Doll, (that thou sayst is thy name) though I had forgotten thee, I protest. About London-wall was it (sayst thou?) Well, I cannot but highly commend thy wisdom in this, that so
well hast mended thy election; from being a fountain of aches, bald brows, and broad plasters, thus to remember thy Creation.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: I did consider, and I think rightly, what I was; and that men that loved my use, loved it but to loath me: Therefore I changed myself into this shape of a demure, innocent Country Widow, that had scarce beauty enough to be tempted, but not wit enough to be naught; and quite forsook the path I trod in, and betook me to this private course of cozenage.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: But all my wonder is at the means, how thou gottest into this house and reputation. And to be held a woman of such an estate.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: That shall be made plain to you hereafter.
Now Brother Geffrey, where left you M Wolsie?

sp.speaker: Crack.
sp.p: Among the Mercers, so troubled, as if all the Satin in Cheapside were not enough to make you a wedding Gown. He is overjoyed that his happy day is at hand; and I over-heard him invite one special friend to his Nuptials. He cannot contain himself. On a sudden he fell a singing, Oh she is a dainty Widow. Oh are you come Sir, in your new shape? Does not that beard fit you handsomely? Thank my acquaintance with the Players.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: I think thou art acquainted any way, to set out knavery.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: If you can perform your part as well, it is well. Hark, I hear him coming.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Where are you sweet Widow? Look you, Look you: How do you like these patterns?

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Sir, here is a Gentleman has a Letter to you: He tells me it imports the making, or the undoing of his dearest friend.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: From whom, I pray you?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Your sometimes neighbour Sir, M: Crasy.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: It shall take effect, doubt not.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: He scratches his head, though.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: He had as lief part with his blood as his money.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: M. Crasy writes to me for thirty pound; the value of a Ring I had of him. I grant I am to pay threescore at my day of Marriage. But we are all mortal. And who knows whether I shall live till tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: If not, Sir, your Bond is due tonight: For it is equally payable at your hour of death.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Oh, but such payments never trouble a man. What the eye sees not---

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Are you in Bonds, M. Woolsie, for your day of Marriage?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Only for this sixty pound. It is for that Ring you wear, and I gave you upon our Contract. It is worth thirty pound ready money.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Then when you are married, you may say you paid the rest for your wife. Pray Sir make even such reckonings before you wed. It will show nobly in you towards your poor Creditor, and be a special argument of your love to me, your wife. Pray discharge it, I shall not think you love me else.

Hark you Sir, if you will take thirty pound in full
payment, and give me in my Bond, here is your money. It is your best course. Alas, I am an unlikely fellow for wedlock. What woman, think you, would bestow herself upon me, a stale Bachelor, unhandsome and poor---not worth above six or seven thousand pound? Do; take thirty pound.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: If you please to befriend Mr. Crasy but with thirty pound, I will set it received upon the Bond. Here it is. And he shall demand no more till it be due.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Pray Sir pay it all, and take in your Bond. You shall be married within these two days; tomororow, if you please: What use will your money yield you for a night? Pray pay it. In truth I will pay it else. It is but threescore pound.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Sayst thou so, Sweetheart. Come Sir. Come in and tell your money---

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: And thank you too, good M. Linsie Wolsie, that knew so well, a bargain was a bargain, and would not part with your money to be laughed at among your neighbours. I would heartily now, if I could intend it. But I must purse your money, and then about my Court affairs. This wench I am infinitely beholden to. She remembers some old courtesy that I have forgotten. Perhaps I piddled with her when I was Prentice.

div2.stage: Scene IV. Enter Sarpego, in gorgeous Apparell.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: This is the Presence. I am much amazed, or stupefied, that Mr. Tobias Sneakup, my quondam Pupil, attends not my Conduct! Ha! So instant was his Grace, his importunity to enjoy me, that although I purchased the loan of Clothes, yet I had not vacation, nor indeed variety to shift my shirt. And now I come to Court, I feel certain little Cattle of infamous generation about me, that do most inseparably haunt me. Now if (when the Prince surveys me) any of them being strangers here, should peep to behold strange sights, and his Grace perceive them, what should I answer?---

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Oh, my glorified Pedantin his most natural strut!

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: I will say it was by influence of the heavens; or, to appear the more perfect Courtier at the first dash, I will say, that though my outside were glorious, yet of purpose I left my inside lousy.
Sed, O Dii! Quem video? None Mr. Sneakup?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: See my worshipful Father-in-Law! Now the Woodcocks shoot into the glade.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Pray ye peace, you must not know me.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: O monstrum horrendum! May not you and I know one another?

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Pray go home, and ask my wife.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Mr. Crasie. Is not one Mr. Crasie here?

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Yes Sir. Here is Mr. Crasie for a need Sir.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Well done: Be bold Sir. Let not your dissimulation be read in your eyes. You know me; give me the Jewels.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Let me alone to present them to his Grace, and praise them, before you are called.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Will you do so Sir?

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Yes; For you know I must not seem to endear them before your face: For that would smell rank of correspondence.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: You say right Sir.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p:
But betwixt us both we will make a shift to cheat him. Stay you here. I will return instantly. Oh Mr. Sarpego! Your Pupil will come and conduct you presently.
Thus sometimes, by deceit, deceit, is known: It is honest craft, by wit to get ones own.---

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: My Quondam Pedagogue!

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: My Nuper Alumnus! Come, present me to the Grace of Greatness. I am ready; behold I am approached according to thy entreats, to approve thy praise, and mine own perfection. Set on: His Grace shall see that we can speak true Latin, and construe Ludovicus vives: Go, set on.

sp.speaker: Tob.
Sar.
sp.p: Sent you not a Nuntius, or a Messenger for me, intimating, that it was his Grace his instant desire, to entertain me as his Instructor?

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Alas, he has over-studied himself! You were best let blood in time Sir.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Sent I not you, by the same messenger, your ten pound?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: My ten pound? Ha, ha ha: I would laugh i'faith, if you could bob me off with such payment.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Sure Sir, you use some Dormitories. Best shave your head, and anoint it with Oil of Roses.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Father! Father!

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Pray peace son. The plot will be discovered else.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: The plot? what plot?

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: The Jewels are sent in. What, I am Mr. Crasie now, you know. I shall be sent for in to his Grace instantly.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Midsummer Moon! Midsummer Moon!

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: In very truth son, hit as it will, I say we are beholding to Mr. Holywater.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Heaven not bless me, if I understand not the Baboons mumpings better than your speech. You are more dark than Delphos. What Holywater?

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Why the Gentleman, you know, you sent to bring M. Crasie to serve his Grace with Jewels.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Father, Heaven pardon me: For sure I have a great desire to call you Coxcomb. I sent no man; nor is there any so stiled as Holywater about the Court.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Do you not want sleep sir?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Or have you not seen a spirit sir?

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Or have you not over-mused, or over-thought yourself, as we doubt Mr. Sarpego, here, has done?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Or has not my mother over-beaten you, father? You may tell me.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Son, I am not so very a fool, but I perceive I am made a stark Ass. Oh son, thy father is cozened; and thy mother will beat me indeed, unless your charity conceal me in the Court here, till her fury be over.

sp.speaker: Ticket.
sp.p: He shall stay at my Wives Chamber.

sp.speaker: Rufflit.
sp.p: And there instruct us in the passages of this cozenage.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Do not weep father. My Lady Ticket will appease all.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Adieu Mr. Sarpego. Lure your brains back again.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Sic transit gloria Mundi. The learned is Cony-caught; and the lover of Helicon is laughed at. The last six-pence of my fortune is spent; and I will go cry in private.

div2.stage: ACT. IIII. Scene I. Enter Crasy like a Dancer.

sp.speaker: Cras.
