sp.p: Now, whilst my politic Mother-in-Law is in expectation of her great adventure, and my worshipful Father-in-Law stinks at Court for fear of her; I in this last disguise will pursue my new affairs. Methinks these Jewels smile on me now more cheerfully than when they were mine own before. First to my honest Punk.

div2.stage: Crack meets Crasie at the doore.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Who would you speak with Sir?

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: With thy sister. Dost thou not know me Jeffrey. Where is she? Look better on me.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Oh, is it you Sir? Hang me if I knew you in this habit; though I was set here on purpose to watch for you.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: What is the matter Jeffrey?

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Sir she is fallen into a new fit of Melancholy. Some new project she has in her noddle. But she desires you to work upon this,
I dare not be seen to talk with anybody.---

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: What new device is this?

Since I last saw you, your Mother-in-Law, Mrs. Sneakup, has earnestly dealt with me to make me a Bride for her son Tobias. If there may be anything wrought out of it to benefit you, I will suddenly take occasion to
break with the Fool Wolsie; of whom I am heartily weary; and after, be wholly disposed by you. Sure this wench studies nothing but my profit. Well: I have thought already to make the best of her. Now to my new Mistress. This is the house, and here is her maid.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Would you speak with any here Sir?

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: With your Mistress, (I take it) Mistresse Crasie.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: May not I deliver your mind unto her Sir?

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: My business is of weight and secrecy: yet you may tell her, here is the Gentleman that her Doctor sent her.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Oh she expects him most impatiently---Pray enter Sir. She is ready for you, there before you Sir---
sp.l: A business of mine own makes me wait here.
I think I saw my learned Love make this way.
But he (alas) though small in fleshly growth,
By reason of his high preferment is
Now grown too great for me.
It is he; I know his stature,
Though not his clothes, the Ensigns of his greatness,
In which how big he seems, though but a sprawler!
So clothes can make men greater, but not taller.
He is deep in study; I dare not interrupt him.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: I have adventured, though with trembling feet,
Unto this Mansion, to exonerate,
At least extenuate my suspirations
For my dear loss. The Lady of this place,
Who had an equal venture, and hath suffered
In the same Fate with me, may ease my sorrow.
Solamen miseris socios habuisse doloris.
I of my wrongs, and she of hers shall clamour.
But ecce noster ubi esset Amor.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Most worshipful Sir, welcome from Court,
If your poor Handmaid may presume to say so.

sp.speaker: Sar:
sp.l: Where is your Mistress? I mean your grand
Matrona, Mrs. Sneakup.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: In the first place let me beseech you Sir,
Vouchsafe your answer to a longing Maid,
That can be comforted in nothing more,
Than the good news of your prosperity;
Of which I hope a part at least to be,
Preferred by your late promise to your service.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: I will now breath a most strong and Poetical execration
Against the Universe.

sp.speaker: [Bri.]
sp.p: Sir I beseech you---

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: From henceforth Erit Fluvius Deucalionis
The world shall flow with dunces; Regnabitque, and it shall rain
Dogmata Polla Sophon, Dogs and Polecats, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: His Court advancement makes him mad, I fear.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: From hence let learning be abomination
Among the Plebeians, till their ignorance
Shall lead them blind into the Lake of Lethe.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: What pity it is that honour and high places
Should make men lose their wits, sometimes their heads!

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: May Peasantry and Idiotism trample
Upon the heads of Art and Knowledge, till
The world be shuffled in the pristine Chaos.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Dear Sir, though you are highly dignified,
Forget not the preferment, that you promised me,
To scratch your head; to make your bed; to wash
Your shirt; to pick your toes, and to evacuate
Your Chamber-pot.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: Elephantem ex Musca facit. She takes me for a Mountain, that am but a Mole-hill.
But when she reads my poverty again,
And that these Garments must return to the gambrels,
Her scorn will be impetuous.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Go find another room maid for your talk,
Mr. Sarpego, my mother calls for you.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Has she received Aliquid novi, news from Court?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: She has now received a Letter. Pray be gone,
I have more serious business of mine own.
sp.p: You are the Creature then that my dear Doctor has sent me, that can dance, read, write, and be secret. I shall use you all in all. And I prithee how fares my Physician?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I can confirm that he is yours protestedly. And tomorrow night---

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Peace: Here comes my mother.
I can my Cinquepace friend. But I prithee teach me some tricks. Who would care for a female, that moves after the plain pace? No: Give me the woman of tricks. Teach me some tricks I prithee.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Ha! Tricks of twenty: Your Traverses, Slidings, Falling back, Jumps, Closings, Openings, Shorts, Turns, Pacings, Gracings---As for---Corantoes, Levoltoes, Jigs, Measures, Pavins, Brawls, Galliards, or Canaries, I speak it not swellingly, but I subscribe to no man.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: It is a rare fellow!

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Am I then cheated? my wit begins to be out of countenance. Oh the Plague that hangs over her head that has a fool to her husband, as thou and I have daughter.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: How now sweet mother? What ill news changeth your face thus?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Oh dear daughter, my Lady Ticket writes here, that the fool, thy father, is cheated of two rich Jewels, that thou and I stole from the Idiot thy husband Crasie.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Oh that Crasy was ever a silly fellow.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: A very Citizen, a very Citizen. How should I call you Sir?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: One Mr. Footwell, Mother; who teacheth Gentlewomen to do all things Courtly, to dance Courtly, to love their husbands Courtly---

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Your name is Mrs. Pyannet, I take it.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Pyannet Sneakup, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Your husband is cozened at Court, I take it.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: So my Lady Ticket writes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cra.
Py.
sp.p: Recompense? Sir command me, command my daughter, my maid, my house, only tell it I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: I pray see wherein we may be grateful. I pray speak.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
So it is, I am a decayed Gentleman, quite out of repair; fallen for want of means to the use of my feet: Nor have I hope to see better light, but only that Love and Fortune have put upon me a right wealthy widow. She lies at a near neighbours house
here; and here I hover about her: but for want of some good friends countenance, some means for clothes and fit housing, she holds off from consummating our Marriage. Now Lady---

sp.speaker: Py.
Cra.
sp.p: The very same.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: (By our Lady a match for my Esquired son and heir. Bear a brain dancer, or I may chance to show you a cross caper.) Sir, bring your Widow. Swear to yourself my house is yours. Now the plot, or I burst.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Why then will I disclose who cozened you; by what means you are injured, and how you may be revenged, only you shall vow to conceal the secret-revealer, else you lose the benefit of further Intelligence.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Stand off daughter: I will not trust mine own flesh with a secret; for in truth I have found it frail. Now speak, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Sure, precious Mistress, very absolute creatures have had Cockscombs to their husbands.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Nay that is indubitable, I know it by myself.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
Marry to be made Cuckquean by such a Coxcomb, to have her Jewels prig'd away, to bestow on a Court Mistress; to have a trick put upon her, as you have, it would move (I must confess) a woman that were not part a Philosopher, and had a strong wit as you have. Why did you not feel the deceit? your husbands unworthiness, having no means to enjoy this Court-Lady but by gifts; and having no course for gifts, but from you, procures some Pander to perform a famed message. Your hope of game puts
the weighty trust upon the counterfeit fool your husband; his simplicity seems cozened, whilst this Lady excuses all, and keeps all: So that your own Jewels purchase your own horns; nay, and you were not withal laughed at for your purchase, it were scarce enough to run mad for.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: It is most plain: I will have such a revenge, as never woman had.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Good Mrs. Pyannet, bear it as well as you may: Your loss is heavy, yet under the strength of your constant wisdome --- I'faith my wife was so careful lest you should take too deep sense of it, that she importuned my own presence to comfort you: For sure I know---

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: You are a Wittally Cuckold I know. I commend thy wives modesty yet: She will not do it afore thy face, but will send thee out of an errand yet.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: What mean you? you amaze me.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Nay, I look you should seem ignorant: What, to take sense or notice of your horn, as long as it winds you into profit, were most uncourtly. Well, you hear not me rage nor rave: marry I will slit the Drabs nose, crop off her ears, scratch out her eyes---

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Bless us!

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Tear off her hair, pluck out her throat, that is all. Come along Sir.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Now they are gone, I prithee
M. Footwell stay a little, I will fetch thee some Letters to read for me, which I have not opened yet, because I durst trust nobody.---

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: These Letters must necessarily come from my Brace of Courtiers, Sir Ticket, and Monsieur Rufflit, which I will read clean contrary, as if they slighted her, and answer them across from her meaning, as if she slighted them: And so letting myself down into their inwards on both sides, what they can get, or what my wife has, will I pump into mine own purse.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Now dear M. Footwell, as ever you pitied the case of a poor Gentlewoman, that would fain use her beauty, whilst there is some pleasure in it, read and answer these Letters with commanding eloquence; force them to affect me.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha: Will you not be offended, if I read them truly?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: No: I prithee what is it?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Stay, it seems you have written to them.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Yes: but I cannot read the answer. Prithee what is it?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Faith you will be angry.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Nay, and you love me, what is it?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Sir Andre where, he says, it is not your broad brimmed hat, your tiffeny dress, Spanish ruffe, and silver bodkin can make him disloyal to his wives bed. Rufflit here, he writes that you have a gross body, a wall eye, a low forehead, a black tooth, a fat hand, and a most lean purse. Aye there is it: And you could but give, and you had but to send---

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: A lean purse!

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
Aye, the lean purse. There is the Devil: Were you as bald as Time, as stiffly wrinkled as frozen ploughed Lands, more dry than a Fever, more lean than
death; had you engrossed deformity, yet if you had but to give---

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Why Footwell, though my husband be but a Bankrupt Knave---

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Nay faith, rather a fool, Mistress.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Well, fool let him be then; yet I have a Mother will not see me want for necessary ends: And I hope I had the wit to cozen my husband of somewhat against a rainy day. Look you Sir, I kept these for a friend in a corner.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Nay, but I would not wish you to send them now: What, relieve the base wants of prating Skipjacks to pay for your damnation?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Nay that is sure, I will not give them:

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: And yet, i'faith, what can a Gentlewoman give too much for her pleasure? Can there be a more heavy disgrace blown abroad upon any Lady, than that she has not at the least two servants, since many Lovers are the only noble approvement of beauty?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: I will send them both, that is sure.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: But both of them to Mr. Rufflit: O he is an absolute spirit! He has an English face, a French tongue, a Spanish heart, an Irish hand, a Welsh Leg, a Scotch beard, and a Dutch buttock.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Oh I: I am wholly his, I will send all to him.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Oh but Sir Andrew, he is a Courtly Lover: He can kiss you courtly, handle you Courtly, lie with you Courtly.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Oh yes: he shall have one. I prithee praise me to them both, and commend to each of them one of these Jewels, not that I do so much care for the use of them, yet because I would not be wondered at like an Owl among my neighbours, for living honest in my husbands absence. I prithee work effectually for me, sweet M. Footwell.

div2.stage: Enter Rufflit, spying her going out.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Mrs. Crasie: Hist Mrs. Crasie.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Peace Sir, forbear: As you would hope, do not pursue a woman when she is out of the humour. Oh, untimely importunity is most distasteful. There are certain seasons to take the coldest Appetite, when she is pinning a Ruffe, playing with a Monkey, hearing a wanton Song, or half drunk.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Oh what are you Sir?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: A private Messenger to you Sir, from the Gentlewoman you pursue. This is your hand, is it not?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Yes:

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: You may keep your Letter.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: But what says my utmost hope, the end of my ambition?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Only that you are poor, a Gallant of a very wanting fortune.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: The more honour for her to redeem me.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Alas, I think her means are but weak, her husbands sinking hath brought her low.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Her husband! Alas poor fly; only made to be sucked and forsaken. His wife has the life-blood of her fortunes in her, and I will be her cupping-glass.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I wonder his wife could nourish so unbelieving a conscience!

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p:
Conscience! All things rob one another: Churches pole the People, Princes pill the Church; Minions draw from Princes, Mistresses suck Minions, and the Pox undoes Mistresses; Physicians plague their Patients; Orators their Clients; Courtiers their Suitors, and the Devil all. The water robs the earth, earth chokes the water: fire burns air, air still consumes the fire.
Since Elements themselves do rob each other, And Phoebe for her light doth rob her Brother, What is it in man, one man to rob another?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: You have spoken most edifyingly sir, but for you, of whom I understand Crasy merits the best Offices; for you to corrupt his Wife, and with a covetous sinning expect use for the loan of your Loins!

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Death man, they are my Exchequer, my Rent: Why I have no possession but my Estate tail. And at for Crasy, he has no wit; he was created a fool, to have Knaves work upon him: a fellow made to have some pity, and all wrong; he had ever an open Purse, and now an empty. He made it a common hole, every Gallant had his fingers in it. Every man loved his Fortune, squeezed it, and when it was unjuiced, farewell kind heart. I confess I owe him a good turn: I will pay it his Wife. He kept her always exquisitely neat; temptingly gallant, and as a protested Cuckold should do, about his degree and means sumptuously proud. Her Eye artificially spirited, her Cheek surphured, her Teeth blanched, her Lip painted, her Neck carcanetted, and her Breast bared almost to her Belly. And shall a piece, thus put out to sale, stand unattempted, as not worth the purchase.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Yes Sir, if you could compass her; as sure she may be corrupted: for she is very covetous.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: If I could but make show of a Gift, or present one---

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Only not to appear of so needy a Fortune--- Why if you chance to possess her.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Push, it were all mine again, and all that she had besides. And troth, I think she is wealthy.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Wealthy! look you Sir, Here are two of her Jewels, I fetched from an Ant of hers, where they lay hid from her Husband. These are not worth the pursuit.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Nay, it is an easy Female: He, that has her, has all. What should I send? A Gift would do it. Let me think. It is but a gross-bodied Wench, with a blackish hair neither.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Oh the better. Your lean No-bodies with yellow Manes have most commonly rotten teeth and wicked breaths. No, your full plump Woman is your only Venus.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: A hundred golden pieces I am entrusted withal by my elder Brother, to purchase a piece of Injustice. If I should send them---

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Oh Sir, these both were yours, and they too. She pretends this strain, but only to explore your strength of means, and to try how far you dare engage them for her enjoying.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: I will send them, win her, use her, suck her Purse, recover my own, gain hers, and laugh at the poor Cuckold her Husband. Commend with these my life's blood, and Souls service to my Mistress. Farewell---

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Sir Andrew Ticket, I take it.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: The same, Sir. Is Mrs. Crasie within? I cannot keep pace with her Mother. Oh, when jealousy is once set a going, it runs on high speed. But let her make haste to arrive at Court, while I land on her Daughter in the City. Is she privately idle?
What dost thou mean by that?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
My Vow is discharged, and her Revenge is done. I am no Pander, Sir, and yet I am of Counsel with Smock secrets, Buttock business Sir.
Are you so stale a Courtier, and know not the necessity of Gifts?

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Is that the matter I am rejected by her?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Why? would it not provoke any Woman to be called fool, and foule-face?

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: I never called her so, by the Soul of my Affection, not I.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: No; Do you not intimate she is a fool, when you hope to enjoy her without a Gift? And foul, when your neglect of cost says she deserves none.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Before Heaven I was a silly Ass, now I think on it, to send a Sonnet without some rich present.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Why Sir? A man must do as he would be done to. Do you, or any man use to be made Cuckold for nothing?

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: I should have sent a Gift. What, if I enjoy her, she may requite it.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: May; Nay can; nay will. Look you Sir, here is Gold. Here are Jewels. They are hers; they may be yours. I would not seem a Pander to you though; for you have a Wife Sir.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Push, who cares to drink out of a River? What I can command out of duty hath but a dull relish. Had not Dane been kept in her brass Tower, she had never tempted a Gods piercing. I must send, though it be but to show the ability of my Fortune, and the desert of her Beauty.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: And then to send but a trifle would disgrace both.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Hold, convey this Carcanet unto her; it is of value, and let her read by this, how much I seek her.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: And how dear you hold her. Sir, I can speak; but I use to take nothing for my pains.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Yes, receive this little---Nay, I prithee.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Only not to appear Uncourtly, or uncivil. I protest I abhor Panderism; only as a second, or so. As you have beheld two Horses knubbing one another; Ka me, Ka thee, an old kind of Courtship.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: I prithee return instantly my success: You shall find me at the Ordinary; come and Dine with me.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I have procured a private Stable for my Horse: And therefore I myself would be loath to stand at Livery.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Dost compare common Stables for Horses, and public Ordinaries for Gallants together.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Troth yes sir, for as in Stables, here a goodly Gelding of twenty Pounds price, and there a raw-backd Jade of four Nobles by him. So at Ordinaries, here a worthy Fellow of means and virtue, and there a Cheating Shifter of wants and cozenage. Here a Knight, there a Beggar; Here a Gallant, there a Gull: Here a Courtier, there a Coxcomb; Here a Justice of Peace, and there an Esquire of low Degree. Or, in direct Phrase, a Pander.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Such a one as thou art.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Umh, Virtue goes often wetshod, and is forced to be cobbled up with base means, to hold out water and cold necessity. You command me no further sir.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: No honest Knave, farewell---

Now Mr. Crasy, will I button up your Cap with a Court-brooch. You demand Debts, do you? I will pay you none. Oh it was a notable dull Flat-Cap. He would invite Courtiers; stand bare, say grace, make legs, kiss his hand, serve us in perfumed linen, and lend us money upon our words, or bare words. Were it not a sin to
let such a fool pass unsucked? No, Fortune dressed him only for us to feed on, and I will fall to.

div2.stage: Scene II. La. Ticket. Sneakup. Toby. Page.

sp.speaker: La. Tic.
sp.p: Be comforted Mr. Sneakup; Remember you are in my Chamber. Bear the heart of a Husband, who scorns to tremble at the face of his Wife? Do not fear sir.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Stand firm Father, do not sink before the face of a Lady.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I have sent my own Husband to satisfy her, and I hope he will do it thoroughly. Be yourself therefore; all the Pleasures the Palace can afford, shall strive to mitigate your fears.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Have you any Pleasures in the Court, can make a man forget he has a Wife?

sp.speaker: To:
sp.p: Sir we have pleasures will make a man forget anything, even himself; therefore necessarily his wife, who is but part of himself.

sp.speaker: La. T.
sp.p: Boy, sing your song of the Court delights.

div2.stage: They sit: Sneakups head in the Ladies lap. The Page sings--- Enter Pyannet with a Truncheon. Sarpego.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Are you lulled in your delights? No pillow for your Goatish head, but her Ladyships lap?

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Oh dear! Oh wife! I did not know you were so nigh truly.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: You are ignorant still, I know: But I will make thy bones suffer as well as my brows. Thou Cullion, could not thine own Cellar serve thee, but thou must be sneaking into Court Butteries?

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Oh, Oh, Oh---

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Væ misero.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Hold dear mother.

sp.speaker: La. T.
sp.p: Sweet Mrs. Pyannet hold.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Art thou there, daughter of an Intelligencer, and strumpet to a Bearward?

sp.speaker: La. T.
sp.p: Now Beauty bless me, was not thy mother a notorious Tripe-wife, and thy father a professed Hare-finder? Gip you Flirt.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: How now Madam Tiffany! Will none but my Cock serve to tread you? Give me my Jewels thou Harlot.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Mother---Pray Mother---

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Bestow steeping thy skin in perfumes to kill the stink of thy paintings, and rotten inwards to catch Cockscombs.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Dear mother.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: But thou shalt not cozen, and Cuckquean me.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Sweet mother---

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Lupus in fabula. The Devil is in the woman's tongue.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: A whip on her; rotten eggs and kennel dirt on her silken Whoreship.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Nil tam difficile. Nothing can lay her.

sp.speaker: La. T.
Py.
sp.p: Did um so? The Country Gentlewoman was more chaste in a Bastard, than the Court Madam in her barrenness. You understand me; you have no Green-sicknesse there, yet (I hope) you have few Christenings; you have tricks for that, have you?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Nay mother---

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: You have your Kickshaws, your Players March-paines; all show and no meat.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Nulli penetrabilis Astro. She will hear no reason.

sp.speaker: La. T.
sp.p: Go to; you know how in private you commended your Horse-keeper to me.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Well: And didst not thou in as much privacy counsel me to contemn my husband, and use an Italian trick that thou wouldst teach me?

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Quid faciendum? Best stop their mouths?

sp.speaker: La. T.
sp.p: Out you bauble; you trifle; you burden smocked sweaty sluttery, that couldst love a fellow that wore worsted stockings footed, and fed in Cooks shops.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Jaculis & Arcu. Thunder and Lightning.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Odds my precious---

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Nay dear, sweet wife---

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: How is this---

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Honey Mother---

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p:
Take this, and take all. Why goody Complexion, thou Rummy Nastiness, thou knowest wherefore
thy Gentlewoman left thee; did she not swear that she---

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: For modesties sake---

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Had rather be at the opening of a dead old man, than stand dressing thy head in a morning. Remember the Page that wore thy picture, and the song which thou hadst in the praise of the male Baboon.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Tacete parvuli: You have said too much.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Indeed mother you will be sorry, when you know how much you mistake, some crafty fellow has put a trick upon you.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Methinks sweet wife you should rather condole our loss with me.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Hold you your peace; do not you prate.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Redde te Harpocratem: The man is wife enough.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: It is true; misfortune hath wrought the Jewels from my father.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Indeed wife, truly, truly, I am Cony-catch'd---

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: But for my father, or this Ladies wronging you, as I am your son, I assure you I have been an eye-witness of all fair respect towards you.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Is it even so?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Mother, as I respect your blessing it is perfect truth.

sp.speaker: Py.
La. T.
sp.p: Alas sweet friend, you and I have been inward a great while, and for us to fall out, and bare one another's secrets---

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Well, it was mine error, not malice; but as for the procurer of it, if I pay not him in his own Coin ---Mr. Footwell! I will show you a trick of twenty. Come son, I have a wife for thee.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: A Wife! a Wife, Mother! Oh where is she?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Aye, my boy, a Wife---

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Oh ho.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: And such a one as thou shalt bless me for procuring. Courteously farewell, sweet Madam: Where is my Fool? Come, leave the Court sirrah, and man your own wife into the City---

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: But I prithee satisfy me: What return they? Received they my Jewels?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Yes, they proved acceptive.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: And what said they? Can they affect?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Can they be damned? Before I will undergo again such a business ---fore Heaven I do as little differ from a Pander! only I have nothing for my pains, or else---

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Thou shalt have. Are thy news happy?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Are your own wishes happy?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Hold, spend this ten pound for me, Footwel.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
Will you make me a Bawd. What a Bawd?
And yet In troth, what would not a man be for your sake, that have such wit and such bounty! I cannot refuse, but suffer your Virtue to be exercised upon me.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: Now, prithee speak; what is their answer?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Why, I will tell you, they are both your own.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: Both Footwell: I prithee how?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Why, no more but this; they are both yours; only you know, but one hand in a Glove at once. But I had so much to do with one of them; such a coil to draw him to it---

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: Which, I prithee? Sir Andrew?

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Even he: He says, he understands that you affect a Mountebank. Sure, your Doctor is but some base bragging Rascal.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Do you think so?

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: How should Sir Andrew know else that he is come to embrace you tonight?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Does he know that too?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Yes marry does he, which the worthy Knight takes so contemptuously, suffering so base a Rival, that he vows, unless you beat him, bastinado him soundly when he comes, he will loath you most constantly.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Enough, if I do not make him an Example to all the bawdy Quacks in the Kingdom; say there is no virtue in Cudgels, and Bedstaves. I will charm him for opening any more secrets of mine, I will warrant him. And so write to Sir Andrew.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Well said Mistress, be resolute. I mean to help you myself.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: I will cast about for weapons instantly.---

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Yes, I will write to Sir Andrew, doubtless, that which he shall have small cause to thank me for. I will write for him to come in the habit of this Doctor.

div2.stage: Scene IV. Linsie Wolsie, Crack with a Lute, &c.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: She is gone, she is gone: Was ever man so cheated? Threescore pound for a Ring; and the Ring gone too, for which I paid it: A months diet and lodging, besides the charge of Physic and attendance. Five pound in dole bread, would have served my house a twelve month. I am undone; broke, Bankrupt: But thou Rogue shalt smart for all, now I have caught thee,

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Mercy, dear Sir, mercy.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Were you making up your pack to be gone too?

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Nothing but my own Sir, my Lute, and a few Music-books.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: You and your Mistress have made sweet Music of me: Therefore sirrah quickly---Are the Beadles gone for?
Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Therefore quickly, I say, as you were an Actor in the Cozenage, bring her to light, or---

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: She is light enough herself: But a very Innocent I, Sir. She has cozened me of half a years service, wrought me off of my legs, strained my back, cracked my voice, done me to my utter undoing; and can you think I knew of her running away?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I will make you sing another song sirrah: Are the Beadles come?

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Any song Sir, or as many
as you please.

sp.speaker: Lin.

sp.p: Yes Sir, they are here.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Dear Sir, let them forbear a little. And if I cannot please you with a song, commit me to their fury.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: It is but to trifle time: yet sing before

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Yet once more, good Sir, try me this last time, and but promise me, if I can sing a song that you shall like, to forgive and free me.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Sing a song that I shall like, and I will free thee.

sp.l: Then shall a present course be found
For M. Wolsies threescore pound;
And his Ring,
And the thing
That has given him the slip---

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Aye marry, that I like well.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Then I have escaped the whip.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Think you so Sir?

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Yes: For you like the song well, you say, and I am free; I hope you will make good your noble City word, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p:
City words use not to pass for songs Sir: Make you good the words of your song, Sir, and I
shall make my word good Sir: Come away Beadles.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Oh stay Sir, I beseech you, and let your Justice fall on the right shoulders. I will confess all.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Oh will you so Sir?

sp.speaker: Crack.
sp.p: It is most true Sir, that the Gentlewoman; whom I called Mistress, is a most cunning whore, and a notorious cheat.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: These are good words indeed!

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: She came to your house with four men in Liveries; they were all but hired Panders.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Yes, and divers Trunks of supposed Treasure, which I find to be Bags of Nails, and other old Iron, and all the Rings and Stones she boasted in her Will are but Curtain Rings, and Brickbats.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Your own covetousness cozened you Sir: But if I now bring you not where you shall see how she is since bestowed, and that you find not hearty cause to rejoice that you were cozened of her, let me be whipped to death, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Well, come along Sir: But I will have a Guard upon you.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: What Guard you please Sir, so my poor skin may scape the Lash-guards.---

div2.stage: ACT. V. Crasy, Tryman, Pyannet, Toby.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Oh thou Varlet, thou unconscionable Unbeliever, ungodly Miscreant! Hast thou cozened my easy Credulity? And wouldst have undone and married me, like a Cony-catching companion, as thou art? Didst not thou tell me, thou hadst moderate means of life, friends of fashion, and civil reputation? And now this virtuous, religious Gentlewoman tells me, thou art an arrant Skipjack.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Nay, and has not a hole to put thy head in, but upon my courtesy.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: But I thank this Matrons worship, her pity will not permit my easy Nature to suffer under thy Cozenage: But bestows her generous Son and Heir here upon me.---

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: A Gentleman of another sphere, another rank than you are Sirrah; that shall have three hundred year in Esse, and five in Posse.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: That is acquainted with young Lords; has had the honour to make a Hunting match.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Aye, and a challenge to ride the wild Goose chase.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: That hath made Ladies Posies for Cheese trenchers.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: And played with Countesses at Shuttle-cock.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: And to this Elegant Spirit and choice hope am I, and my Fortunes contracted.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: How! contracted.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Yes Sir, contracted. Look you, I dare seal it before your face.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Are you so.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: She is mine sir, mine sir. Do you mark, I dare likewise seal it sir.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Is there honesty in this dealing?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Yes sir, Is there not profit in this dealing?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: It is very well. If there be no Law upon words, Oaths and Pre-contracts, and Witness. If a man may spend a hundred Angels upon a Widow; have her affied before Witness, and then have his Nose wiped of her. Why, It is very well.

div2.stage: Tryman takes Pyannet and Toby aside.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: In truth dear heart, and sweet Mother in expectation, to speak equally, there have some words of course past betwixt us, which may seem to impart some Engagement. Surely I have been too liberal of some speech of advantage. Truly it would not be amiss, (considering his Expense and Interest) to fall to some 'slight Composition. Some hundred Pounds would make the poor Knave do anything.

sp.speaker: To.
Try.
sp.p: For if he chance but to be delayed till he ask Counsel, then---

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Mum. A word to the wise.---

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Nay, I hope as long as I am a Subject, I shall have Law: I doubt not but I shall have Law.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Come Sir, you shall not deservedly exclaim of my neglecting you. For our sometimes Love, I have procured you a hundred Pounds.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: To disclaim my right in you, I will take it. Here is my hand, I will take it.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Pox, how my Mother stays.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Scorn my Poverty! Come, where is it? Because I have not the Muck of the World. Come, the money.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Here sir, upon this consideration, that you disclaim and renounce all interest---

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Yes most freely.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: In this Gentlewoman; and do vow, never to pretend future claim to her.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I do, marry.---

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Nay, no marries sir, you have received the money. You shall make no more marries here. Come my betrothed Spouse, bid a Fice for him, Say black is thine Eye who dares. Mother I will be married tonight, and to bed presently.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: This night, Son; it is very late.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: never too late to be wise. I hope I am your Son; and must bear a Brain.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Indeed, he that deals with Woman, must take occasion by the fore Lock. Away---

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
Why! I am weary of money now: I have gotten more in a weeks Cozenage, than in all my days of Honesty. What an easy cool thing it is to be a rich Knave! Gramercy Punk. A witty Wench is an excellent help at a dead lift. But in despite of the Justice that provoked me, my Conscience a little turns at these
brain-tricks. But they have all been ungrateful; ungrateful! It is a sin that should have no mercy: it is the Plague-spot; who has it should not live.
sp.l: If holy wisdom from the thundering Cloud
Had given more Laws than ten, this had ensued:
Avoid, Oh man, man's Shame, Ingratitude.
For my poor Lot, I could have sweetly slept
In quiet want, with resolute content,
Had not defect of wit, uncourteous scorn
Been thrust upon me. Now they all shall feel,
When honest men revenge, their whips are steel.
My Courtiers are the next that I must exercise upon. This night my wife expects
the embraces of one of them at least, if this hasty Marriage call her not from her Chamber.
But she being a right woman may prevent that with a fained sickness, or so. Let me remember,
I wrote to Rufflit to come like her Doctor Pulse-feele, to minister to her. This will jump right
with a counterfeit sickness: It may, perhaps, break a Urinal about his Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Musick.
sp.p: How now! Oh perceive this great Wedding goes forward.

div2.stage: Musick. Torches. Sarpego. Toby and Tryman. Sneakup and La. Ticket, Pyannet. Josina in night attire, Bridget. They passe as to the Wedding with Rosemary. Crasy whispers Josina. She takes leave of her Mother, seeming to complain of being sick; and so returnes with Bridget. Then enter Rufflit like a Doctor.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: So, this falls out pat. She is no sooner gone Sick to her Chamber, but here comes her Physician, to cover and recover her in a trice.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Hist, Footwell, Footwell.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Seignior Rufflit; I am a fool if I took you not for a Physician.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: She wrote to me, that I should come in this habit.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Right Sir, to avoid suspect: For which cause she has counterfeited herself sick, and lies longing and languishing till you minister to her.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: And am I come pat? am I come in the nick?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Your Fortune sings in the right Cliff, sir, a wench as tender as a City Pullet.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: But not so rotten.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Oh sir, health ifself; a very Restorative. Will you in? The way lies open before you.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Hold Footwell, tell that till I return---

from branching the most merited Cuckold Crasy. Poor Snake, that I must force thee to cast thy Skin. If he were not a Citizen I could pity him: He is undone for ever. Methinks I see him all ready make earnest suite, to wear a red Cap, and a blue Gown; comely to carry a Staff-torch before my Lord Mayor upon Alhalloune night. Watch Footwell, I mount.---

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: But now, if the agitation of my Brains should work through my Brows. If my Wives pitiful hand should fall to composition with my Doctors Pate, and my deceit be discovered before the Bastinado had given charge to his Shoulders, were not my Forehead in apparent danger. It is done in three minutes. Death, my Courtier has a sanguine Complexion: He is like a Cock sparrow, Chit, Chit, and away. Heart of man! And I should be blown up in mine own Mine now! Ha.
Hold Mrs. Crasy. Dear Bridget. Help Footwell.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Ho the hubbub is raised, and my fear is vanished.

div2.stage: Enter Josina, and Bridget beating Rufflit : Crasy takes Bridgets Cudgell, and laies on.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: Out you Pispot-caster.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: You Suppository.

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: You Glister-pipe, thinkst to dishonest me?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Hold, dear Lady---I am---

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: A stinking saucy Rascal thou art, take this remembrance.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Hold, sweet Mistress.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Oh I thank you good Mr. Footwell.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Oh, it is not so much worth verily.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Oh, but it is sir.
sp.stage: He draws his Sword from under his Gowne. Crasy closes with, and disarmes him.
sp.p: Rogue. Rogue. Nay prithee sweet Rascal, Pox on you, I did not mean to hurt you, my honest Vagabond, tell me, tell me: Come, who was it put this Trick upon me. Thou art a precious Villain: Come, whose devise was it? Whose plot. At whose Suit was I Cudgeled? Who made me feign myself a Physician, till I must be forced to go to the Surgeon? And darest tell me?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Nay, then I will tell you. Dare! why it was your Friend and Rival, Sir Andrew Ticket.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Ticket.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Even he sir. His Gold hired me to gull you. And this brain procured your beating. Yes faith sir, Envy, bribes, and wit have wrong upon you.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Well, if I revenge not---

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: But how sir.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Aye, afore Heaven, that is well thought on. Give me but the means, and I will not only forgive, but reward thee richly.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Come faith, because I would have both your Shoulders, go in one Livery, I must disclose. Why sir, Knavery is restorative to me, as Spiders to Monkeys. The poysou of wit feeds me.
sp.stage: Enter Ticket. Boy with a Torch.
sp.p: Look you sir, he is come. Stand close, take this Cudgel, grasp it strongly, stretch your Sinews lustily; And when you see him hang by the middle in a Rope, let your Fist fall thick, and your Cudgel nimbly.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: And soundly. My ambitious blows shall strive which shall go foremost.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: Good sir.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: draw him up but half way.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: So sir, I must up to receive.---

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Do so: I shall be so revenged now! He had been better have been taken in Bed with another man's Wife, than have prevented me thus.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Vanish Sirrah with the Light. This I am sure is the Window which her Letters called me to.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: I would you would begin once, that I might be at work. I do not love to stand idle in the Cold thus.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Hist, Footwell, Footwell.

sp.speaker: Crasy above:
sp.p: Here sir, here. Oh I watched to do you a good turn. Will you mount sir?

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p:
I will mount, remount, and surmount. I wonder that there is not a solemn Statute made, that no Citizen should marry a handsome Woman; Or if he did, not to lie with her. For if it were not for Gallants
help, they would beget nothing but Fools.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Right sir, right sir. Take the Rope, and fasten it about your middle sir.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Why, that is Crasy; a very Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: An Ass, an Ass.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: A mere Citizen. Were it not a shame his wife should be honest? Or is it not pity that my own man should wholly enjoy a rare excellent proper woman, when a whole Corporation scarce affords two of them.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Most true sir. Now mount sir. I pluck courageously. Pray Hercules my strength fail me not.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Up sir, up sir.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Pox, and pain! Hold Doctor.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Save you sir.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: I am most sensible of your Salutation. Pluck Footwell.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Alas the Cord sticks-sir; I will call some help sir.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Death and Devils!

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Fists and Cudgels.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Heart, Lungs, Lights.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Arms, Shoulders, Sides.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Help, help, help.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Passion of Heaven Doctor: I will Doctor you away.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Redeem me dear Footwell

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Yes sir I come for the same purpose. Alas sir, methinks I even feel your blows. Are you not sore sir?

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Sore? Couldst thou not pluck?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Sure I was Planet-struck; the rope stuck in a slit Sir.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: A Pox on the slit, say I.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Know you this mad Doctor? Or do you owe any Doctor anything?

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: I know him not; nor do I owe any Doctor anything; I only owe my Barber-Surgeon for a diet-drink.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Speedily make up your face Sir,
sp.stage: Ent. Rufflit in his owne shape.
sp.p: here comes company: M. Rufflit!

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Honest Footwel! how dost? Sir Andrew! Heartily how is it?---

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: As heartily as thou wilt; but not so hard I prithee.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Why what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: I bruised my side even now against a forms edge.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Parmasity, Sir, is very good, or the fresh skin of a flayed Cat.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Flayed Cat?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: The fly-blows of a dead dog, made into oil, and spread upon the kell of a measly hog.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Hark Gentlemen, the Wedding comes, forget old bruises, and put on sense of the lightest colour: for this house tonight vows to run giddy with mirth and laughter.

div2.stage: Enter Lights: Sarpego, Toby, Tryman, La. Ticket, Pyannet, Sneakup.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Joy, health, love and children to this happy union.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Unbruised bones, and smooth foreheads to you both.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: What shall no device, no mirth solemnise my sons match? Go Sneakup, call down our daughter.
In despite of sickness, mirth and joy shall make this night healthful.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Oh mother, cold sobriety and modest melancholy becomes the face of the Matron; unedifying gauds are Profane vanities. Mirth is the fat of fools, only virtue is the nourishment of purity and unsinning sincerity.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: By the leave of your wisdom daughter, we will take the wall of your preciseness: for Mr. Sarpegohas told me of a learned subject for a Ballet, which we shall see acted presently.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: What is it, some Heathenish Play?

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: No certes, but a very religious Dialogue, full of nothing, but moral conceits betwixt Lady Luxury, a Prodigal and a Fool.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: But who should act and personate these?

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Why in that lies the nobility of the device; it should be done after the fashion of Italy by ourselves, only the plot premeditated to what our aim must tend: Marry the Speeches must be extempore. Mrs. Bride would I have to play Dame Luxury, and Mr. Footwell here the Prodigal.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: And my husband the Fool.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Aye, if it please you wife.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: I will play the Inductor, and then we are all fitted.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: I pray you what is Lady Luxury? A woman regenerative.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: A Whore, wife:

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: In sincerity not much better than a Courtesan; a kind of open Creature.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: And do you think me fit to represent an open Creature? Saving your modesties, a Whore. Can I play the Strumpet, think ye?

sp.speaker: Jos.
sp.p: Trust me Sister, as long as it is done in private, in ones own House, and for some few selected Gentlemen's pleasure; Methinks the part is not altogether the displeasingest.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Modesty defend me! you think it is nothing to play the Strumpet.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Why surely religious Lady, it can be no disgrace to you to figure out the part: For she that cannot play the Strumpet if she would, can claim no great honour to be chaste.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: How gravely and sententiously he speaks.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Wife, it shall be so: It is my first Injunction; you shall do it, or disobey me. You must play it.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: What, the Whore sir?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Aye, in jest: What hurt is it? And Mother, you shall excuse my Father for this once: For since my wife plays the Whore, I will play the Fool myself. Though, I know, you had rather see him do it, you shall see for a need, I can make shift to perform it as well as he; as naturally, and to the Life.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Exceeding well thought on, I pray you, Lady, approve of it.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Let learning direct, I am not to prescribe to the Muses.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Come sweet heart, let us in and tire us, and be ready to enter presently.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Now for the Prodigal.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
Oh doubt not, Mr. Sarpego: For know Sir, I am but a poor serving creature, that lives upon expectation;
Oh Sir my end must be husks. Fear not my discharge of the Prodigall---

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: Nil nisi Carmina desunt.
To entertain ye, while we attire ourselves.
We want but now some Music, or a Song,
But think you have it. Sit: we will not be long.---

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Seat you Gallants. Sit, sweet Sir Andrew, Madam, and the rest, and we will imagine Music, as M. Sarpego bids us.
sp.stage: Enter Linsie Wolsie, and Crack with his Lute.
sp.p: How now! By what misrule comes he to trouble us?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: By your leave, Gallants, I have brought you Music.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: You Sir, I know your purpose, and it is prevented; you come after the Marriage to forbid the banes. Ha ha ha---you are short, M. Wolsie, you are short.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Good Mrs. Sneakup you are wide. I come to wish joy to the match, and to tell you I rejoice, that I missed a Bridegrooms part.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: How is that?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: You see I wear no Willow, and am merry. All is true you told me, boy?

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Yes by my detestation to Bridewell Sir.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Sing boy that song, If I have any grief, it shall be all vented in a Hymeneall Song.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: I have not known him in this humour.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Sure it is a merry madness for the loss of the widow,

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Since you come friendly, you are welcome, M. Wolsie. Pray sit with us, and hear your Hymeneall Song.

p.foreign: Jo Hymen, Jo Hymen, Jo Hymen

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: This begins well.

sp.l: Was wont to be still the old song
At high Nuptial Feasts
Where the merry merry guests
With joy and good wishes did throng:
But to this new Wedding new notes do I bring,
To rail at thee Hymen, while sadly I sing.
Fie Oh Hymen, fie Oh Hymen, fie Oh Hymen,
What hands, and what hearts dost thou knit?
A Widow that is poorer,
And a very very Whore,
To an Heir that wants nothing but wit.
Yet thus far, Oh Hymen, thy answer is made,
When his means are spent, they may live by her trade.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: He sings Hymen and Hymen; but methinks the song is scandalous to the Marriage.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Excuse me Lady, though I was cozened of the Bride, I have no such malice; it is a song that the boy could sing by chance, and made by a couple that were lately married in Crooked-Lane.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Oh, is it so Sir? I knew not what to make of it.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Let us attend I pray; the Prologue enters.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: Right Country Dame, and Courtly Lady,
Look for sense as small as may be;
But, if wit deceive your thinkings,
Know our Muse disdains base shrinking.
Hold a while your Verdicts bridle,
Judge not yet our Project idle,
Till at length the close may show it,
If we act the part of Poet.
sp.stage: Enter Tryman and Toby. She loosely drest like a Curtezan, a bowle of wine in her hand. He in a fools Cap and Coat.
sp.l: Speak Lechery and Folly, Luxury I would say;
I need not prompt them, they know what they should say.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Out you base Rascal, you muddy Slave; thou hast married me, and I will drink a health to thy Cuckold maker.---

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Sfoot I am afraid she will play the whore better then I shall act the fool.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Thou under-hearted, dull-blooded Pantaloon; thou whose utmost honour is to be made so good a thing as a Cuckold; thou son of a Copy-holder, and the Pudding-pie woman's daughter, dost thou think, darest thou but imagine, that I shall ever vouchsafe to love to do anything, but laugh at thee? Hence you Poltroon; thy voice sounds not so far as thy breath stinks---

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Nay but, nay but do you hear wife? I do not very well like this; methinks you play too much in earnest.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: In earnest? Why Goodman Fool, you Coxcomb, you Ninnihammer, you Clotpold Country Gentleman, thou dirty greediness.---

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Why how now daughter? Are you well? Methinks you over-do it too much.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p:
Thou dreamest my good husband, that thou
hast married the rich widow, ha ha ha---

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Now enters Prodigality.

div2.stage: Enter Crasy in his own habit, all hung with Chaines, Jewells, Bags of Money, &c.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: When the troth is, dear brother, you have married the rank whore. Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Sir!---who, brother Crasy?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Sweet husband!

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Dear son!

sp.speaker: Tic., Ruff.
sp.p: Precious friend!

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Neighbour Crasie!

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: And how do you wife? When comes your Doctor Pulsfeel? But a kiss and so forth? And would not one of these free Gallants, these proper youths have served the turn? I pray pardon mine incivility, Mother; I was bold to retain mine own Jewels. Have you not forgot your singles and your doubles, your fallings back, and your turnings up wife?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Why i'faith, dear heart, dost think me so simple, that I did not know thee all the while? Alas man, I did but counterfeit, as you did, to maintain the jest; kiss me sweet duck --- only to maintain the jest i'faith.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Yes, yes, yes, we are Friends. I heartily thank these kind Gentlemen for their loves to you, yes faith, heartily: I am better by it five hundred at least. Be not you jealous Madam, they had nothing for it; not a bit by this Light.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Death of my Fortune! that was my Gold.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Plague of a Villain, that was my Jewel.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: True Gentlemen; and your bounty likewise lies in this Bag.

sp.speaker: La. T.
sp.p: Sir, we sent these things to your Wife.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I thank you for it; we have but one Capacity in the Law, you know: What is hers must be mine. I know thou wouldst have it so sweet-heart. I am only sorry Gentlemen, that you were so well favouredly beaten. That the Fool Citizen, the Ass Citizen, the Cuckold Citizen should procure such a sound swaddling to your wise, valiant and substantial Shoulders. Is it not a sore matter? But rest, Salves and warm Oils may in time recover it. How do you kind Mother? Gentlemen, if any of you want Money Gentlemen, here stands a City-wit that has it. I have it, if you want any; speak, I have it, and will keep it. How does your Costard Sir? A Pox of the Slit, Sir. Beloved of Phoebus, Minion of the Muses; dear water bayly of Helicon, be not proud of your Preferment, though you are his Highness tutor. Mother, I take the restoring of my rich Jewels very kindly. Oh my kind Brother, you have got the rich Widow; and you have borne a brain Mother. Your hundred pound, brother, was most thriftily and opportunely bestowed. I could have procured her to you at an easier rate, Mother. I am only sorry for you Mr. Wolsy, that you had her not: Because you very honourably released me of your Bond before it was due; and are in shrewd danger to be laughed at among your Neighbours. How does good Mr. Crasy, the Princes Jeweller? Mother, did not my Father look too wise for a Citizen? How dost honest Punk? I am as much beholden to thee, as to the rest of them.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: My son and my heir is utterly undone.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Oh! I am quite cast away.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Oh no, you shall be no loser by me; you shall be a gainer by me Brother: Get wit Brother (mark you) wit. Good faith I pity the poor Citizen, he has no wit; a handsome young fellow, with a pretty beard, and a proper bodied woman to his wife, and cannot bear a brain!

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Why dost hear, modestly mumping Mother-in-Law, with thy French-hood, gold-chain, and flaggon-bracelets, advance thy snout. If the fool thy son, the Idiot my husband here, have but as much brains as a Battledore, he may make a fair revenue of me: Has he not a place at Court? Can he not lodge me there, and prove weak-sighted, thick of hearing, sleepy after dinner, and snort when others entertain and Court me? Can he not survey the hangings, read Cupids Conybery, the Park of pleasure, Christian Love-Letters, or some other Pamphlet, or fain some errand into the Town, whilst his brows are turning into gold?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Oh impudence beyond woman's apprehension! Son Crasie, we have all wronged thee, thou knowest it; thou hast revenged it, we feel it; only do not undo my heir, save him, bring him but off of this match with any loss.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Why mother, is your son grown such a saucy Knave, as he thinks scorn to be a Cuckold? I cannot clear him; in truth I cannot: He has paid for her deeply, and it is pity they should be parted, yes faith is it.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Woman, we do pray thee, we do beseech thee, even upon our knees---have pity on the house of the Sneakups: quit my son, relinquish
thy right, make frustrate this marriage, and look thee, before these able witnesses, we heartily forgive all, and forget: And withal, freely bestow this chain upon thee---

div2.stage: [Pulls off her chain and gives it.]

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: I do receive it.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: She does receive it, bear witness all, she does receive it.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Marry on this condition---

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: No I will no more marries nor conditions, you have received it.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Aye, you must make frustrate the Marriage; for look you, you have received it.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: I will, and freely do; only the condition I would have made, is this, That if you intend longer to be Master of your husband, now that you have seen how well it became me, you will henceforward do as I do---Look you, wear breeches.

div2.stage: Puls the coats up, and shews the breeches.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Oh horrible!

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: How! do you wear breeches?

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Yes Sir, breeches; and as good lining and stuffing in them, I hope, as yours have, though they be of Satin.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: I will feel that: Sfoot mother this is a man. Come and feel else.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: A young one Sir.
See Master your poor servant Jeremy, if he has performed his part, desires to be admitted into the Livery of wit, and to wear this chain as his ensign of Freedom.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.p: Jeremy!

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Jeremy! Oh Jeremy! thou wert ever too hard for---

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Except at spoonmeat, Sir.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Ieremy!

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Yes, Mistress: Indeed forsooth.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Well, give me thy hand: I will love thee as long as there is swiftness in meditation, smoothness in flattery, or constancy in malice.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: And for the cure that he has wrought on me,
I will applaud his wit, and bless the light
It gave me to discover my foul error:
Which by his demonstration showed so monstrous,
That I must loath myself, till I be purged.
Sir, by your fair forgiveness, which I kneel for---

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.l: Heaven make me thankful: Wife I have no words
To show how I rejoice: Rise, let me kiss thee---

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.l: Tempora mutantur. The town is ours again.
Only, to fill the Scene with joy, may we
Conjoin sweet maid, in the Catastrophe.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Would you that have taught Greeke, and whipped great boys, come back to your Horn-book, and let down your Gascoines to me, that would, if I had you, be more tyrannous than any Pedant that ever reigned since the days of Dionysius: Besides here is my choice, with my Master and Mistresses leave, Jeremies brother.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: But is he seriously thy brother?

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Yes, and no more a Pimp Sir, than I am a Wench.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Sarpego, I will help you to a fitter match, and Crack I will give thee something with her: Take the security of my hand.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: I only desire to be secure from this man's fury, and so consequently from Bridewell.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: He shall have nothing to say to thee.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I will have nothing to say to man, woman, or child, while I live again.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Fortuna nihil aufert sapienti: Fools and Fiddlers are her Favourites.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Let us make this a merry night.
Think of no losses. Sirs, you shall have none;
My honest care being but to keep mine own.
What, by my slights, I got more than my due,
I timely will restore again to you.

sp.speaker: Omnes,
sp.p: Thanks kind Mr. Crasy, thanks.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Gratias vel ingentes Domine Crasy.

sp.l: Now let me Scholastikewise
For us all Epilogues:
If these slender Scenes of Wit
Are received, as they were writ,
For your mirth, and no offence;
Let your Grace quit our suspense
With applaused Catastrophe.
I am short, with ye (as you see)
There a Figure, which pray note ye,
valete valetote.
Gratias Reddo Cuicunque.
Valetote Iterumque.
FINIS
